Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5S23-NP91-DXH2-632S-00000-00Trump Administration Talking Tough On Beijing and Moscow; Chinese Repercussions Could Impact Upcoming Elections; New Russian Sanctions; London Now Has Higher Murder Rate Than New York; English Hospital Seeks Ruling To End Life Support; Trump Vs. Press, President Won't Attend Correspondents' Dinner; Assault Weapons Ban, Lawsuit Challenges Deerfield, IL New Ordinance2018-04-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:27ZLexisNexisFOX NEWS @ NIGHT11:00 PM ESTJulian Epstein, Sarah Westwood, Vince Coglianese, Penny Nance, David Bruno, Emily CompagnoNEWSInternational040601cb.259Trump Administration Talking Tough On Beijing and Moscow; Chinese Repercussions Could Impact Upcoming Elections; New Russian Sanctions; London Now Has Higher Murder Rate Than New York; English Hospital Seeks Ruling To End Life Support; Trump Vs. Press, President Won't Attend Correspondents' Dinner; Assault Weapons Ban, Lawsuit Challenges Deerfield, IL New OrdinanceShannon Bream, Ed Henry, Gillian Turner, Juan Williams, Jason Chaffetz, Trace Gallagher, Greg Palkot

SHANNON BREAM, FOX NEWS HOST: Hello and welcome to FOX NEWS @ NIGHT. I'm Shannon Bream in Washington.

Wall Street and many in D.C. are telling the Trump administration as being tough or reckless with China by playing a high stakes game of chicken over tariffs. But many of the same critics say the president isn't being tough enough with Russia even after a new round of sanctions directly squarely -- directed squarely at President Vladimir Putin's inner circle. We're taking a close look at the president's policies on both fronts tonight. We've got team coverage. Gillian Turner, examining the latest round of Russian sanctions. And chief national correspondent, Ed Henry is here with the latest on the tariffs patch rattling the markets. Ed.

ED HENRY, FOX NEWS CHIEF NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: Shannon, the fact that President Trump promised over and over in the campaign to get tough on China is pretty straightforward. What's complicated is that by keeping that promise, there could be some real economic costs, as we saw with the markets today and some political ones in the fall with the midterms. The president did a radio interview here in New York today, which he said this talk of a trade war is silly. In many ways, we already lost the war. China's cheating, he said, has been ignored by Republican and Democratic administrations. He added, it killed thousands of American factories, millions of American jobs and now we're stuck with a $500 billion trade deficit with China.

Here's the thing, even anti-Trump columnist and commentator, Fareed Zakaria, acknowledged today in the Washington Post, "President Trump is right. China is a trade cheat. Previous administration exerted pressure privately, worked within the system and tried to get allies on board with limited results." Getting tough on China, he writes, is a case where I'm willing to give Trump's unconventional methods a try. Nothing else has worked.

But the markets were rattled in part by confusing signals by the president's own team. His treasury secretary, Steve Mnuchin today, flat out admitted there is in fact a potential for a new trade war. Even as the president's new chief economic advisor, Larry Kudlow keeps trying to calm everyone down by suggesting all of this is just a careful negotiation to use threats that might get China to make even minor concessions that struck a level playing field. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL: We are considering adding tariff pressures. Considering. I don't want to disrupt the economy. The president doesn't want to disrupt the economy. We need not disrupt the economy. This is a moderate tempered approach that we are taking. It is moderate, temperate, and proportional. This is not a trade war.

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: But we're going to have a much stronger country when we're finished. And that's what I'm all about. We have to do things that other people wouldn't do. So we may take a hit. You know what? Ultimately, we're going to be much stronger for it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HENRY: Well, all of that contributed to the rollercoaster markets along with this statement from the Chinese government. "The Chinese side will follow through to the end and will not hesitate to fight back at any cost. We're prepared and have already formulated very detailed counter measures.

Well, those measures are where the midterms come in play. China is being very crafty about directing their fury at Midwestern battlegrounds, yes, in Trump country. States where soybeans, corn, tobacco farmers may take a hit not just in 2018, but last I heard, Shannon, there's another election coming in 2020.

BREAM: So there is. All right, Ed. Thank you very much. Some on Wall Street are calling it the tariff tantrum. The latest wild swing in the market attributed to an uptick in trade tension between the U.S. and China. All three stock market indices losing at least two percent today and all closing lower for the week. Industrial stocks, especially those with big stakes and China's growing industrial economy like Caterpillar, Boeing and Deere were among the Dow's hardest hits. Always important to remember, there's time for Beijing and the Trump administration to reach an agreement before a made deadline, but traders appear to be pricing in a worst-case scenario which would be an all-out trade war.

Well, Moscow responding tonight as President Trump's last new sanctions on dozens of Russian oligarchs and government officials. Some companies there as well. Gillian Turner is monitoring it all, joins us with the latest. Good evening, Gillian.

GILLIAN TURNER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: The new round of sanctions are intended to severe 17 senior Russian government officials, seven oligarchs and 12 companies from the international financial system and prevent Americans from doing business with any of them. They also include targets intended to hit close to home for President Putin. One of the key targets is his very own son-in-law, a high profile oil executive married into Putin family in 2013 and shortly thereafter became a billionaire.

Another key target, a close childhood friend of Putin. Now an oil executive and long-time head of Gazprom. The Russian state controlled their natural gas giant. The White House touting the moves as proof President Trump is prepared to get tough on the Kremlins.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: The totality of the administration's actions which are in keeping with Congress's wishes prove the president is absolutely correct when he says no one has been tougher on Russia.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TURNER: One of the oligarch's named in the sanction is Oleg Deripaska, a one-time colleague of Paul Manafort. President Trump's former campaign manager and adviser. In the wake of the U.S. announcement, shares in Deripaska's energy company took a tumble. And he had some harsh words for the sanctions calling them groundless, ridiculous, and absurd.

The Russian embassy in Washington put out its own scathing response with an official statement reading, "Washington has delivered yet another blow to Russian-U.S. relations. Now, the sanctions cover captains of Russian business refuse to play to Washington's scenario."

Some Democratic lawmakers used the sanctions announcement as an opportunity to point out President Trump's seeming reluctant to take a hard line on Putin himself.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. GERRY CONNOLLY (D), VIRGINIA: This president has been sending mixed messages to the Russians and to Vladimir Putin personally that make you wonder, is there a consistent policy?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TURNER: Administration officials however were quick to defend the president's stance.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NIKKI HALEY, U.S. AMBASSADOR TO THE UNITED NATIONS: Russia is never going to be our friend. But having said that, that doesn't mean we don't want to work with them. But we work with them when we need to and we slap them when we need to. That's just the way it needs to be.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

TURNER: The treasury department says these sanctions are a direct response to Russia's arming of the Assad regime and Syria's ongoing civil war and Russian cyber operations. All of this comes, Shannon, just days after American diplomats expelled from Russian, landed back home here on U.S. soil. Shannon.

BREAM: All right. Gillian, thank you very much for the update. Well, the president claimed back in February via Twitter that he's been tougher on Russia than President Obama ever was. So, is it true? Let's talk about it with Juan Williams, co-host of "THE FIVE." And former Utah congressman, Fox New contributor, Jason Chaffetz. Great to have you both tonight, gentlemen.

JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS POLITICAL ANALYST: Nice to be with you.

JASON CHAFFETZ, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Thanks, Shannon.

BREAM: OK. So let's start on the left. Scott Dworkin this. He's from the Dem Coalition. He says the weakest -- he says to the president, "You're the weakest president ever. The B.S. sanctions. But he spelled it out. You place on select Russians and companies can't be trusted. Nothing you do can. This is all so you can act like you're tough on Russia when in reality, we all know you promised Putin something in return. Jason?

CHAFFETZ: I don't know who that Dworkin is, but it sounds like a pretty ridiculous statement. Factually, President Obama was very weak on Russia. It started when he pulled out the missile defense from Poland. That was viewed as a gift to the Russian people. They tried to do this fictitious reset with Russia. They mocked Mitt Romney for his comments about the severity of the Russian thread. They really didn't do anything. But President Trump has done a lot, including a $100 billion plus-up in our military, which the Russians can't keep up with and these new rounds of sanctions that have gone on. And it was the Russians, by the way, that were accused of actually poisoning somebody there in the U.K. We're supporting our NATO allies. We've built a bigger, broader coalition and had more of an effect on Russia than anything Barack Obama ever did.

BREAM: OK. Let's bring in Juan here. Now, Juan, Byron York wrote a piece about this and he said, when this conversation came up, I reached out to a GOP lawmaker who immediately sent me this list. Bombing Syria, Russia's main client, unleashing the U.S. military in Syria, including against Russians when necessary, arming Ukraine, browbeating NATO allies to increase defense spending, adding low-yield nukes to our arsenal, starting research and development on an INF non-compliant missile and shutting down Russia's San Francisco consulate. So, what do you think in comparison to the Obama years?

WILLIAMS: Well, I think the best case for Donald Trump is to say I've been tougher in my first term than Barack Obama was in his first term. But I think that if you start to look at the record and this is not just a matter of my opinion, when you go look at PolitiFact, the Washington Post, the New York Times, they all say that when President Trump, President Trump first said, I'm tougher than Obama ever was, then in fact this was not true. Why do they say it's not true, Shannon? They say it's not true because if you look at an issue like for example, Ukraine, the United States government, under President Obama was quite aggressive in telling President Putin to get out, sending forces. In fact, we sent our CIA director over there to help the Ukrainian forces. Secondly, congressman Chaffetz mentioned --

CHAFFETZ: But that's not what happened, Juan. They took Crimea. And they kept it.

WILLIAMS: No. But let me just say that what happened there was they were going to expand to take Ukraine. They --

CHAFFETZ: But they didn't take Crimea and they did not pull back.

WILLIAMS: But they didn't, congressman, because President Obama was tough and the threat of U.S. tough military power laid them back off.

CHAFFETZ: Didn't push them out of Georgia either. They took 25 percent of that country.

WILLIAMS: OK. And then you mentioned the missile defense. Again, we moved the missile defense from Poland and guess what, Putin cried bloody murder, he said that we were in fact expanding NATO, coming into his orbit and that it was too aggressive. That was President Obama.

CHAFFETZ: But he pulled it back, Juan. We're already under George W. Bush, we were going to put the missile defense in Poland. One of the first things Obama did is pull it back.

WILLIAMS: No. In fact, we included Poland in NATO and we moved the missile defense. So it was still effective in countering all of the Russian missiles which is why Putin was so upset. But again, this is about -- I think the real argument here is President Trump always trying to vilify President Obama, compare himself to Obama. That shouldn't be the point. The point should be that he should speak aggressively against Putin at this moment and he never said a word moment about Putin's meddling and interference in our 2016 election.

CHAFFETZ: I agree.

BREAM: And maybe that with you two on that point of agreement, I mean, that is one of the issues too that Byron brought up in his piece. He said, for some people who are critical of Trump on the issue of Russia, is that they haven't seen the kind of reaction they want to see with regard to election issues. But when you look at the list of the other things, there is a debate to be had and you guys had a good one.

WILLIAMS: I love it. I can talk with Jason Chaffetz either. He's a smart guy.

BREAM: I know. He probably feels the exact same way about you.

CHAFFETZ: Thanks, Juan. I probably not going to tweet that up.

WILLIAMS: No, don't do that. We want to protect your base, brother.

BREAM: We got to protect both of your guys. Juan and Jason, the two Js. Have a great weekend. Thank you both.

WILLIAMS: You too, Shannon.

BREAM: All right. The first of 4,000 national guardsmen ordered by President Trump to the Mexico border are now deploying. Arizona and Texas each offering up hundreds of guardsmen in a first wave.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BRIG. GEN. TRACY NORRIS, ASSISTANT DEPUTY ADJUTANT GENERAL OF THE TEXAS MILITARY DEPARTMENT: This initial phase of deployment will include command and control, coordination cells and operational planning as requested in support of the federal entities already on the border. Follow-on forces will move to the border once mission requirements and locations are finalized. As early as tomorrow, notifications will go out to soldiers who will be called up as part of the follow on phase. This notification will allow guardsmen, soldiers and airmen to notify their families and employers and the corporations to report as early as next week.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: Well, Texas already has 100 guardsmen deployed as part of an existing state mission at the border.

Tech giants including Facebook, Google and Twitter being sued by survivors of the Pulse nightclub massacre for allegedly providing support and resources to ISIS. Trace is going to join us with that story.

And Facebook Sheryl Sandberg apologizes for the Cambridge Analytica fiasco. Saying the company was wrong, they're changing things and they hope to get it right moving forward.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SHERYL SANDBERG, COO, FACEBOOK: We did not do enough to protect people's data. I'm really sorry for that. Mark is really sorry for that. And now we're taking very strong action to get ahead of the problem.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: And Apple's CEO, Tim Cook defending his company's decision to stream NRA TV but with a warning, coming up.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: You can bet that we continue to monitor and if it walks into the path of hate speech or some of these other things, then we're cutting it off.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: Next week shaping up to be a big one Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg. He's already under fire from Congressmen Anna Eshoo who represents his home district. The company is also facing a new lawsuit and new criticism over its basic business practices. Trace Gallagher has more details for us tonight. Trace?

TRACE GALLAGHER, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Shannon, even if you're worth $60 billion, sometimes you got to feel the heat. And members of Congress are planning in putting Facebook founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg's feet to the fire. His appearance comes on the heels of the Cambridge Analytica scandal that exploited the information of some 90 million Facebook users. And so privacy will likely be the primary topic. Iowa GOP Senator Chuck Grassley, chair of the Judiciary Committee says "with all of the data exchanged over Facebook and other platforms, users deserve to know how their information is shared and secured." And Zuckerberg can forget hometown favoritism. Democratic Congresswoman Anna Eshoo whose district includes Facebook says she plans to how to ask how Facebook was used to "damaged our Democracy" and how the company has shaked politics. Zuckerberg will also be asked about plans to make sure and information is disseminated fairly and that political sources are fully vetted.

And while next week's stands to be tough on Zuckerberg, this week hasn't exactly been a cake walk. Facebook along with Google and Twitter are being sued by 16 survivors of the Pulse Nightclub massacre in Orlando, Florida. The sued alleges the tech company has violated the anti terrorism act and profited by allowing ISIS to spread propaganda. And a group of civil society organizations in Maynmar are now blaming Facebook for the spread of hates speech that may have put thousands in danger. They're referring to two separate chain letters that warned impending attacks by Muslims and Buddhists.

The group has alleged that Facebook never picked up on the fake letters until they were alerted. And even then it took days to take down the phony information. And then there were the leaked comments made by Facebook Vice President Andrew Bosworth in a 2016 memo where he wrote that connecting people was paramount no matter the consequences. "Maybe it cost a life by exposing someone to bullies, maybe someone dies in the terrorist attack coordinated on our tools and still we connect people." Mark Zuckerberg says he strongly disagrees with the memo. Shannon?

BREAM: All right. Trace, thank you very much. So feeling the heat, Facebook today announced new policies aimed at increasing transparency and accountability in their so called issue ads. But will that satisfy the tech company's growing course of critics. Let's bring in tonight's panel, Julian Epstein, former chief counsel for the House Judiciary Committee. Sarah Westwood, the Washington Examiner's White House Correspondent, and Vince Coglianese, the editorial director for the Daily Caller among many other things. All of you have many multiple jobs. So thank you for taking time out to visit with us tonight.

VINCE COGLIANESE, EDITORIAL DIRECTOR, THE DAILY CALLER: Thank you.

BREAM: Good to have you all. OK. So, let's talk about one of these things that Trace, in light of those comments back five, six, seven years ago from one of the Facebook executives, this new lawsuit that's been filed by the Pulse survivors saying this, they say, without the sentence, Twitter, Facebook, and Google, YouTube, the explosive growth of ISIS over the last few years into the most feared terrorist group in the world would not have been possible. They say the company refused to actively monitored networks to block ISIS's use of the service. Julian, you're an accomplished lawyer. Does this go anywhere?

JULIAN EPSTEIN, FORMER CHIEF COUNSEL, HOUSE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE: Maybe not this case but this is one of a number of cases that have been made, arguments that have been made. Congress just passed a law because many critics were saying that Facebook and these big tech companies were used to enable sex trafficking. So Congress just passed overwhelmingly a bipartisan law. And most of these companies, people don't know it, your viewers don't know it, have immunity from many of the laws that would otherwise hold them liable.

So, there is a large party of critics that has said Facebook and Google have enable terrorism, sex trafficking, the theft of television content, movie content, music content and enabled all kinds of other antisocial activity. I suspect the parent company of t his Fox News core is very concern about Facebook's stealing, enabling the stealing of television content and posting it on their sites for free. This is one of the many problems that big tech has. Privacy is a big problem, the enablement of antisocial conduct like sex trafficking, like terrorism, another problem. Lots of critics saying they have anti-competitive abuses. This is not just a privacy problem they have. They're in a world of hurt. Sheryl Sandberg didn't help this morning with her interview.

BREAM: Well, I want to play a little bit of what she had to say today on some of the issues.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SANDBERG: If you are running not just an election ad, so you're a candidate but you're running an issue ad and we're going to publish a list of issues, we're going to verify who you are. You're going to have to tell us your location, your identity. If you won't tell us that or we don't think it's correct, we're not going to let you run.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: Sarah, those were comments to our Dana Perino today. What do you make of it?

SARAH WESTWOOD, WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT, WASHINGTON EXAMINER: Well, I think, look, like Julian said, we're sort of having this conversation as a society about what responsibility these social media platforms have to their users, have to shield them from content that could be offensive to police, illegal activity and what responsibilities users have to be responsible for their own data, to take steps to protect their own information. We're learning that maybe, you know, social media companies don't have your best interests at heart at the end of the day and that you do need to take steps to protect yourself. It's interesting though because a lot of these social media practices have been in use since at least the 2008 election but they're only now sort of coming into the spotlight because of the severity with which they were exploited during the 2016 election. And there is a bit partisanship injected into the debate now.

BREAM: Well, Vince, what do you think? Do you think that there would be this aggression in cleaning house over some of these issues had Hillary Clinton won?

COGLIANESE: No. Not at all.

BREAM: Seriously?

COGLIANESE: I don't. I don't think there would be any sort of push like this toward social media companies that Hillary Clinton won. The reason for that is we've known all along what Facebook does. It gathers -- the reason we use it for free is because we're trading our privacy for access to it. We've been doing it for years. And no one has really made a stink out of it. I mean, there are -- probably a couple of people who noticed of it. Never had a Congressional level. The reason it's gotten to this moment now is because it all started a couple weeks ago with the Cambridge Analytica scandal. The fact that that organization was connected to Donald Trump has been used as yet another pretext for why Donald Trump won the election rather than just simply beating Hillary Clinton in a political contest. Now Mark Zuckerberg is being called to the Hill. Would he be called to the Hill for testimony net week, were not for the fact that a Trump-associated organization in any way was connected to this? No, I don't think so. This is I think nakedly partisan because -- and -- but it's about time that we look hard at the access to which these companies have to our privacy.

(CROSSTALK)

EPSTEIN: I think there were lots of criticism about social media practices before Trump won and even before Cambridge Analytica came on. I think to your point, it's interesting. Steve Bannon is the person who's out there saying that big tech ought to be treated like utilities. Lots of criticism coming from the right about censorship concerns.

COGLIANESE: Yes, yes.

BREAM: Right.

EPSTEIN: I think rather than partisan , it maybe -- the -- Cambridge Analytica might be partisan but there's a growing bipartisan chorus of voices on the left and right saying that needs to be regulation, these guys need to be held accountable.

BREAM: Well, we'll get two days of it next week up on the Hill when Zuckerberg is there. Thank you panel. Please stick around because we got more hot topics for you. In the meantime, coming up. A sky high murder rate. London beseech by violent crime stabbings and homicides. The mayor says he needs help.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SADIQ KHAN, MAYOR OF LONDON: The Prime Minister meet with me and the Commissioner to try and fund the national solution to these national problems, she said no. I'm also looking today to meet with me and the commissioner to see if we can solve this together.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: And a two-year-old in a fight for his life. His parents say they've got hope. But the hospital says time's up even the pope is waiting. Penny Nance says it is time to push back against government decisions that should be left to parents. She joins us live when we return.

BREAM: One year ago, London's mayor boasted his city was the safest in the world. Now it's getting more dangerous by the day. What happened? Here's Senior Foreign Affairs Correspondent Greg Palkot.

GREG PALKOT, FOX NEWS SENIOR FOREIGN AFFAIRS CORRESPONDENT: Shannon, for a city long known for its civilized behavior, the bobby on the beat, London has a problem. The murder rate here for February and March was -- believe it or not ahead of New York's. The city of similar size and population and quite a history. With guns harder to get here, 35 of London's 55 homicide cases in 2018 were knife incidents. Many in the rougher areas of the city. Scotland Yard on Friday holding an emergency sessions with authorities and community leaders. Center-left Labour London Mayor Sadiq Khan was on the defense of this week. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KHAN: To families, I'm incredibly sorry. I mean, particularly, one loss is one -- too many, many bereaved families attended to funerals. It's deeply, deeply upsetting.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PALKOT: What's behind this increase? The center-right conservative government in the U.K. has made some pretty big across the board 20 percent cuts in recent years, not just in policing but also social services. Expert says that could have an impact on this. Also, as in the State, the stop and search approach to dealing with suspects has been sharply curtailed amid an increase in crime overall in the U.K.

Still, even with New York's murder rate way down from the old days, London will still have a way to go to match that. Last year in 2017, New York saw 290 killed. Here in London, the figure was 134. Shannon.

BREAM: Greg, thank you very much. Well, a 2 year old boy is caught in a middle of a legal battle over his life. Alfie Evans is suffering from a degenerative neurological condition. He's been hospitalized for more than a year in England.

Well, hospital official says there is no hope of recovery. And they've gone to court to get permission to remove any life-sustaining measures. Alfie's parent say, he's been increasingly responsive and they've been searching for alternative treatment options. They say they've been talking about that with the hospital, so now they feel blind-sided about the hospital's request to end Alfie's life.

The case has many similarities to the last year's Charlie Gard case. That little boy died in London after a legal battle over his care. And both cases, the pope has weighed in publicly, supporting the parents and their fight to try to take their children elsewhere for care.

Penny Nance, president, and CEO of Concerned Women for America worked to help Charlie Gard's parents last year. She joins us now to talk about these new case with Alfie Evans. Thanks for coming in.

PENNY NANCE, PRESIDENT, CONCERNED WOMEN FOR AMERICA: A heartbreaking case.

BREAM: I mean, this is really difficult because -- let me read you at the hospital has said about why they think it's the end. They say, "We always aim to reach agreement with parents about the most appropriate palliative care plan for their child but sadly, in this case, we have not been able to do this. Consequently, we must return to the High Court, as we are legally required to do, for guidance about a date on which to draw treatment from Alfie." Now, the parents say, they've just been in the meeting with the hospital --

NANCE: Right.

BREAM: -- and they thought they were going to have a chance to maybe take him somewhere else.

NANCE: Right, they felt completely blind-sided by this, you know. The standard for you surfing parental rights in the U.K. is a lower standard than here. And that's part of the conversation that's going on now. But it's a serious issue and it continues. And by the way, you know, doctors don't always get it right, and parents love their children the most, more than any all these well-intentioned medical experts.

There was a case three years ago, His name is Eisha King, a little 5 year old boy who had a cancer's brain tumor. And his (INAUDIBLE) for being told they couldn't have the treatment that they were seeking, a specialized treatment, they took him and ran. They ran just -- they went to Spain first. So, it tipped off this like national -- this international incident. They were arrested, held for 48 hours.

Finally, the U.K. backed down, they took him to the Czech Republic. He got the treatment the parents were seeking, and he's been -- he's been cleared of cancer now. And they just interviewed him and he said he wants to grow up to be a chef.

So, least that was a happy ending, and maybe it wouldn't be a happy ending. But the issue is parental rights. What rights do the parents had have versus the heavy-handed government, which in this case is the political health system and the U.K. And parents are losing.

BREAM: Well, and this is what the mother said. This is a statement on Facebook that attributed to her after the meeting she had with the hospital. She said, "They said they would review the new evidence and they put aside the talks of end of life until the new medical evidence would be reviewed and we were able to seek a second opinion. We are disgusted in what they've done and how they can get away with this." And they'd -- like Charlie Gard's family --

NANCE: Right.

BREAM: -- they've crowdsourced funding --

NANCE: Right.

BREAM: -- so that they could take them somewhere else. And a lot of people -- regardless of where they are on socialized medicine or anything else --

NANCE: Sure.

BREAM: -- are kind of like -- listen, if the parents think there's a shot somewhere and they raised the money and they're not asking the government to pay for it, why not let them go?

NANCE: And this was shocking, all right, this is the U.K., this is isn't third world dictatorship. They have socialized medicine and they have can complete control. Even though Charlie Gard's parents raised 1.3 million pounds and these parents raised 50,000 pounds, they had hospitals both cases that were willing to continue treatment in this case with Alfie -- little Alfie. The Vatican's hospital in Italy said, "Bring him, we'll try to continue to help him." The parents need to be respected and there is a real right to life issue, but there's also a real parental rights issue in this cases.

BREAM: Well, and a lot of people come question whether -- you know, it's expensive to keep this child alive.

NANCE: Correct.

BREAM: In a place where medical care is very carefully --

NANCE: Rationed.

BREAM: I don't want to use the word, rationed, but you know, I mean, they have to make tough decisions about who gets treatment that's playing in this case, as well. Penny, thank you for coming in.

NANCE: Thank you.

BREAM: We'll keep an eye on this case, and let us know if you hearing anything.

NANCE: Sure, I will.

BREAM: All right. When we return, Obama looks back on the 2016 presidential election. That's First Lady Michelle Obama, and she is still unhappy with you, the American voter.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHELLE OBAMA, FORMER FIRST LADY OF THE UNITED STATES: The best-qualified candidate in this last race was a woman. And she wasn't perfect, but she was way more perfect than many of the alternatives.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

OBAMA: The eight years that Barack was president, it was sort of like having the good parent at home. And now perhaps, we have the other parent in the House. And we thought it feel fun. Maybe it feels fun to some for now because we can eat candy all day.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: Former First Lady Michelle Obama, making some waves comparing President Trump to an irresponsible called fun parent. So, let's talk about it with our panel tonight. Julian, Sarah, and Vince are back. All right, Sarah, I will start with you. You know, that's how some people feel.

WESTWOOD: Certainly, I think a lot of critics read that comment as condescending, sort of part and parcel of how the left has viewed a lot of Trump supporters. All these two plus years now that President Trump has been on the political scene that Democrats have treated people who support him and treated his ideas with condescension. A sort of try to invalidate them or something that just sort of totally beneath the reasonable discourse. And as long as Democrats continue to do that and they don't try to engage with Trump and his supporters in a meaningful way, then they're leaving themselves vulnerable to Republicans and Trumpism to continue to dominate because they just don't understand -- they still don't understand what is sort of fuelling his popularity.

BREAM: Well, this is what Tony Shaffer, had to say in a tweet with the London Center for Policy Research, our viewers will recognize and know Tony. He says, "We're not children, the metaphor is sickening and demeaning, and shows how little they thought of the American people. Michelle Obama: My husband was the good parent compared to Trump. Vince?

COGLIANESE: Yes, I agree. I don't think the issues viewed as condescending. I think it is condescending because -- I think it portrays sort of the perspective of the Obama family. Which is that the presidency is one in which they're the parents to the American people. They are in charge, they tell you when bedtime is, they tell you I need your vegetables, they tell you when to shut up and what you should be doing with your life.

And I think, the average American voter views it very differently that they're in charge, actually. And that the -- we elect the president of the United States to serve us, the sorts to be civil servants.

And she also sort of -- I think she forgets why Donald Trump was elected and the role her husband played in building the momentum towards his election. She's just -- she's making a scene like we sleepwalk into the Trump presidency, we didn't. And then, the trump presidency is an answer in very many ways to her husband's presidency.

BREAM: What do you make of it Julian? May does it minimize the serious policy things that President Trump has attempted to do and the things he has gotten done like the tax cuts?

EPSTEIN: Well, so, I wouldn't have used the metaphor, but I think you can get lost in the analysis of the metaphor and miss the larger point. I think the larger point that she was making is that he does tend to act very unpresidential. And she's not the only person that made it, the Republican leader of the Senate, Mitch McConnell has made that point, Bob Corker has made that point, and number of Republicans in the House and Senate have made that point.

It's not really all that much different from what many Republicans have said. It's not really all that much different from what the American people said. 60 to 70 percent of the American people think that he acts unpresidential. So, I mean, I think I would have found a different way to say it, but I think there is that point. And I think whether it's the scandals or whether it's the daily tweets acting like a triumph to the insult dog and assaulting everybody that disagrees with you, criticize with you --

(CROSSTALK)

BREAM: But there were you -- but there are millions of people who --

EPSTEIN: I don't really think -- I don't think that's hurting the Democrats. I think right now the wave is moving in the other direction. I don't see any evidence that (INAUDIBLE) Democrats.

(CROSSTALK)

COGLIANESE: There's a difference -- there's a difference from being upset with the tone of the president and the behavior of the president. And what -- by that, I mean, President Obama, had an imperial presidency. He expanded the power of the executive in a way that no other President before him had. The use of executive power going after the press in real ways, not calling them fake news. Using the Justice Department to go after The New York Times, going after the associated press --

BREAM: James Rosen.

COGLIANESE: James Rosen, time and time again.

EPSTEIN: We can have that debate.

COGLIANESE: It is a debate because there's the actions of a president and the tone of a president. And while you may disagree with President Trump's tone, President Obama's behavior, I think warrants a lot more scrutiny and is very -- is a lot of more troubling to the American people.

BREAM: All right. I want to get to our next topic. And Sarah, since you covered the White House, again, we'll start with you. The president looks like for a second year in a row will not be attend -- attending the White House Correspondents' dinner. It's a tradition here in D.C., but he is not besties with the press.

WESTWOOD: Absolutely not. It would force him to share a stage with specific journalist who he has attacked for spreading so-called fake news. I think it would be sort of, disingenuous for him to move from attacking members of the presses he called them novelist today.

(CROSSTALK)

BREAM: He do. He said they're novelists who don't have sources to makes it well.

WESTWOOD: People who invent sources, sources who -- you know, rubbing elbows with them in the swampiest of environments, obviously, you know. The dinner is a great opportunity to celebrate the first amendment. To celebrate -- you know, people who cover the White House, but also, I think it's very much not in keeping with the Trump brand, so it makes sense for him to stop.

EPSTEIN: I think it's a good point but I think, it also overlooks another point, which is that I think, I somewhat sympathize with what Trump -- how Trump feels about the White House Correspondents' dinner. It's kind of a narcissistic celebration of self by the Washington political class. And to your point about being out of touch with Middle America, I mean, I think that resonates well.

WESTWOOD: It does.

EPSTEIN: And a few word just to say it like that and leave it at that, I think he would do well. But he takes it too far, and he says, "I'm going to engage in this war on the media." And you know, all of the polls show that he's losing that war with the media, most of the American people, if you put him at a head to head matchup, Donald Trump versus Fox News, they believe Fox News. Donald Trump versus CNN, they believe CNN. Donald Trump versus MSNBC, they believe MSNBC.

(CROSSTALK)

BREAM: But we've -- but we have seen -- we have seen about the polling. We've seen polling as well --

EPSTEIN: The polling all bears it out. It's not an argument that he's winning.

BREAM: -- that says the American people have a great distrust of the media.

EPSTEIN: Yes. But the point is -- that's exactly the point, they do and the distrust has been growing.

BREAM: Right.

EPSTEIN: But as he attacks the media, he's losing that debate with the American people.

COGLIANESE: The approval rate -- the approval rate in the media is clearly rock bottom. Also I found it interesting this week that the Monmouth University released a poll said that when people think of fake news, they often actually think of the editorial judgments of these news organizations and not explicitly fake facts. They don't like that they're spending all these times in stories that they think that the American -- the American -- the average American doesn't care about.

BREAM: Yes, trust me, our Tweeter feed folks weigh-in every night and we love to hear from you and we love to hear from our panel. We are out of time but thank you all for giving us your Friday night. Good to see you.

EPSTEIN: Thank you.

BREAM: All right, the Second Amendment under attack. While a Chicago suburb has banned assault weapons and many other firearms and magazines as well, now residents are fighting back. There is a freshly filed lawsuit.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: When you want to disarm your citizens because you do not trust them, you go against everything that our Constitution is about.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BREAM: All right, tonight, we take it to "NIGHT COURT." Our attorneys are standing by to present their cases. You are the jury at "NIGHT COURT" when we return.

BREAM: Time now for "NIGHT COURT." We pass no judgment on these stories but present them to you, the jury, for your consideration. On the docket, this Monday Deerfield Village in Illinois voted unanimously to outlaw possessions, sale and manufacturing of what they're calling assault weapons, many other firearms and some magazines as well. The new ordinance also fines gun owners up to $1,000 a day if they don't turn in their weapons or get rid of them by the June 13th deadline. Now, one resident of the town and two gun owners advocacy group are filing suits. So our legal eagles are here to break down the case. David Bruno, a Criminal Defense Attorney who is arguing for the ban to be upheld and Emily Compagno, a former Criminal Defense Attorney who is arguing against the assault weapons ban. Welcome to you both.

DAVID BRUNO, CRIMINAL DEFENSE ATTORNEY: Hi Shannon!

EMILY COMPAGNO, FORMER CRIMINAL DEFENSE ATTORNEY: Thank you.

BREAM: OK, I want to start by reading a little bit of what we got from the Second Amendment foundation that one of the plaintiffs in the case, they say this. While the village is trying to disguise this as an amendment to an existing ordinance, it is in fact a new law that entirely bans possession of legally owned semi-auto firearms with no exception for guns previously owned or any provisions for self-defense. It certainly puts lie to the claims by anti-gunners that nobody is coming to take your guns. David?

BRUNO: Yes, the fact of the matter is there is precedent on this. And it comes from the same state in the Circuit Court's 7th Circuit. And that in essence said that yes, they can legislate and ban assault weapons. There's a United States Supreme Court case Heller that dealt with handguns at a D.C. and that did not squarely answer that question. So when this court is going to have to decide, they're going to have to look to that seventh circuit precedent that -- and they'll have to follow it, and this is a Constitutional law therefore.

BREAM: Well, David, one of the crazy things that I was reading about in this case is that one of the plaintiffs actually he lives in a neighboring town where they passed a similar ordinance. So he picked up and moved because he didn't want to get rid of all his guns. He's an instructor. He's is licensed and permitted gun owner. So he moved to Deerfield Village and now they have outlawed -- you know, the reason he moved there. This is what he said. He's said to require lawful owners who have been background checked multiple times to dispose of lawfully owned property is not the way do this. We are literally the safest members of your community.

BRUNO: Yes, here's the interesting point about that. He should move and go somewhere else. There's a whole United States.

BREAM: He's going to keep it, the gun laws will follow him.

BRUNO: Keep on going. You know, there are a number of states that outlaw assault weapons and particularly in this state, not every single municipality has this ban. So he should pick up and leave.

BEAM: OK. Emily, this is what the village attorney said when this was introduced and they voted on. He said it's any opinion it's entirely lawful, this draft ordinance, under the Second Amendment, as a valid regulation of assault weapons, and as a valid home rule ordinance to amend the villages prior regulation of assault weapons to ban assault weapons, the possession, manufacture and sale of them in within the village of Deerfield. He says it's going to hold up to legal scrutiny. You heard the case that David cited.

COMPAGNO: Right, now, this ordinance is undeniably unconstitutional and here's why. In part, it defines high capacity as any ammunition feeding device that can accept higher than ten rounds. So in effect, it includes most hand guns. Now, David is right to cite the Heller case from the United States Supreme Court but in fact it does squarely fit here with precedence. They reasoned that the Washington D.C. ban on handguns and regulation that lawfully owned rifles and shotguns was unconstitutional because as they ruled, the Second Amendment protects an individual's right to possess lawful firearms unconnected with the militia for traditionally lawful purposes such as defending themselves in the home. Now, obviously Washington D.C. is federal jurisdiction so in 2010, the Supreme Court ruled that yes, it does apply to the states. Which means here the states cannot infringe on an individual second amendment right. This will not pass muster.

BREAM: All right, well, the Major there says this. We hope that our local decision helps spur states and national leaders to take steps to make our communities safer. She has said, that's Harriet Rosenthal, that she really hope this will inspire other places to do the same thing. We know that the neighboring town did it. That's why the plaintiff moved to this one. David says he hopes that he continues on. I mean, Emily, what do you think are long term implications of this if the court upholds this ordinance and says yes, this is fine, townships can do this?

COMPAGNO: If the United States Supreme Court upholds this, yes, we will see that starting to spread but they won't simply because again, merely seven years ago the court ruled that this is unconstitutional. And this isn't about -- and I will say, too, let me interrupt myself to say that the overbroad language of the ordinance simply won't fly either. Given that the court, the United States Supreme Court has issued and ruled so specifically and so strongly that the Second Amendment is protected, there's no way that any exception could be carved out with the broad language that this ordinance states, including again that definition of high capacity ammunition. So here nothing will fly.

BREAM: Well, and David, I thought it was interesting. I went through and read the ordinance. It's several pages long and there was a specific provision that used to be in their local ordinance that said there's no legal liability if you use one of the guns for self-protection for yourself, you know, threat of bodily harm or someone else. They completely axed that out. That's completely taken out now. So I mean, obviously the idea is they say you have to get rid of your guns or destroy them. Police can take possession of them if they're used as evidence and then destroy them. I mean, they're really saying, you know, they're not confiscating them per se. You just have to get rid of them. They'll take them if you don't get rid of them. For a lot of folks that feels like a real threat to their Second Amendment right.

BRUNO: No, I agree. But you know what, this is much bigger than Deerfield. This is about the Second Amendment and whether or not it applies to assault weapon. And to rebut Emily's point here. Those arguments were raised in the Seventh Circuit Cause and the U.S. Supreme Court had the opportunity to take this case and decide.

BREAM: Yes, they didn't.

BRUNO: The Third was denied. Justice Thomas wrote a descending opinion there. They had the opportunity, they passed.

BREAM: Yes, we got to leave it there. We'll see because there's a lot of people who want the Supreme Court to step in on these and to wave but --

BRUNO: Sure. We need some certainty here.

BREAM: -- without four votes of four Justices, it's not going to happen. All right, guys, thanks very much. Great to see you tonight. And please tweet us @ShannonBream or either of our legal eagles to let us know how you'd rule in the case if you were sitting on the jury. In the meantime, most watch, most trusted, most grateful that you spent the evening with us. Have a fantastic weekend. Good night from Washington, I'm Shannon Bream.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WK7-54J1-DXY4-X10G-00000-00Trump Administration Warns of Threats With Cryptocurrencies2019-07-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:27ZLexisNexisSection BColumn 0Business/Financial DeskPg. 3Trump Administration Warns of Threats With CryptocurrenciesBy ALAN RAPPEPORT and NATHANIEL POPPER; Alan Rappeport reported from Washington, and Nathaniel Popper from San Francisco. Jeanna Smialek contributed reporting from Washington.

WASHINGTON -- Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said on Monday that he has ''very serious concerns'' about cryptocurrencies, including the one being developed by Facebook, the latest indication that Washington is preparing to exert its power over digital currencies.

In a briefing at the White House, Mr. Mnuchin said cryptocurrencies pose a national security threat because they can be used to fund illicit activities. He also said that the Trump administration was ''not comfortable'' with Facebook's plans to begin a digital payment system, called Libra.

The warnings come after similar comments by President Trump, who said in a series of Twitter posts last week that he was ''not a fan'' of cryptocurrencies and that their value was volatile and ''based on thin air.'' Mr. Trump warned Facebook that it must seek a banking charter and follow all bank regulations if it wants to be in the digital currency business.

The Trump administration has said little about cryptocurrencies in the past two years, despite their growing popularity. Mr. Mnuchin has largely described the new technology for creating, moving and storing money as a potential consumer protection issue rather than a threat to the financial system. Regulators have long focused on how to minimize crime in the cryptocurrency industry, but it has tended to be a wonky issue that has not attracted much public attention.

But Facebook's announcement of Libra has spurred Washington's interest in cryptocurrencies.

The chair of the Federal Reserve, Jerome H. Powell, said last week that the central bank had ''serious concerns'' about Libra and had been in contact with Facebook regarding its project.

This week, the House and Senate will hold hearings to examine Libra, and lawmakers plan to grill David Marcus, the Facebook executive who is overseeing the project. Facebook was asked to cease work on the project until it addresses lawmakers' concerns.

Facebook's crypto foray has renewed attention on the thousands of cryptocurrencies that flourished after the original digital currency, Bitcoin, which was released in 2009 and envisioned as a new kind of money that would not be controlled by any government or central authority.

Bitcoin was presented by its mysterious creator, Satoshi Nakamoto, as a largely political project, aimed at challenging central banks and governments.

But from the early days, Bitcoin gained traction among people looking to make illegal transactions online. The Silk Road, an online market for illegal drugs, was started in 2011 and became a booming business, with every payment sent in Bitcoin.

In recent years, there have been many legitimate businesses set up around cryptocurrencies. Most of these businesses are focused on using Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies as investment products, similar to gold.

Several large financial institutions, including Goldman Sachs and Fidelity, have begun to offer products related to Bitcoin to their customers.

This mainstream validation has helped give Bitcoin a sheen of legitimacy and pushed up the price of the digital token. But it has also led to increased volatility in the price of Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies.

The price of a single Bitcoin soared to nearly $20,000 in early 2018. Since then, it crashed to $3,000, but has risen swiftly again in recent months to around $12,000.

Bitcoin has also become the standard currency for ransomware operations in which victims lose control of their computer to remote hackers. Victims are able to get back their files only if they send a Bitcoin payment. Many cities have lost control of their computer networks in these kinds of attacks.

On Monday, Mr. Mnuchin cited the use of Bitcoin in terrorist financing, tax evasion and human trafficking, though so far, law enforcement officials have brought few cases in those areas.

''The Treasury Department has expressed very serious concerns that Libra could be misused by money launderers and terrorist financiers,'' he said, adding that ''we will not tolerate the use of the cryptocurrencies in support of illicit activities.''

Facebook does not intend to release the currency until next year, but the company has big ambitions for the project, which it hopes will become a new global currency and the foundation for an alternative global financial system.

Those ambitions -- and Facebook's broader reputational problems -- have made the project such a lightning rod for controversy.

''We know we need to take the time to get this right,'' Mr. Marcus, the Facebook executive, said in testimony released ahead of the Senate Banking Committee hearing. ''And I want to be clear: Facebook will not offer the Libra digital currency until we have fully addressed regulatory concerns and received appropriate approvals.''

Facebook has designed Libra so that it will be run by a Swiss association governed by at least a hundred companies and other partners, rather than just Facebook itself.

When Facebook announced Libra, it said it already had 27 partners, including big players like Uber, Mastercard, Visa and Spotify. But so far those partners have largely remained silent and Facebook has borne the brunt of the scrutiny facing Libra.

It is clear that Facebook will be facing a raft of new regulations and public scrutiny as it proceeds.

Mr. Mnuchin said that cryptocurrencies must comply with the Bank Secrecy Act and register with the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network. They must also meet the same anti-money laundering and counterfeiting standards as traditional financial firms.

The Treasury secretary also expressed concerns about the speculative nature of Bitcoin and about Facebook's problems protecting the privacy of its users.

''Our overriding goal is to maintain the integrity of our financial system and protect it from abuse,'' Mr. Mnuchin said.

The Trump administration's concerns about Libra appear to be bound up in the president's broader distrust of the social networking giant. Mr. Trump tweeted about Libra soon after a social media summit meeting in which he criticized Facebook and other big tech companies, accusing them of silencing conservative voices, including his.

Mr. Mnuchin insisted the administration was not trying to retaliate against Facebook. ''No, we're not going to target any one entity,'' he said. ''Everybody is playing by the same rules.''

Mr. Powell, the Fed chair, expressed similar concerns about Libra last week, telling lawmakers it could not go forward ''without their being broad satisfaction with the way the company has addressed money laundering, all those things.'' He also raised data privacy and consumer protection concerns, saying, ''All of those things will need to be addressed very thoroughly, and carefully, in a deliberate process that will not be a sprint to implementation.''

Skepticism about Libra, and cryptocurrencies more broadly, represent a rare issue where the Trump administration and some Democrats are united. Last week, Senator Sherrod Brown, Democrat of Ohio, called on the Fed to protect consumers from Facebook's ''Monopoly money.''

''The largest banks and the largest tech companies do not act in the interest of working Americans, but in the interest of themselves and their investors,'' Mr. Brown said. ''The Fed must take a proactive role to ensure that the payments system remains accountable to the public.''

However, Republicans have tended to be more sympathetic to the cryptocurrency industry, and have positioned it as something that the government should be working to protect as a check against government and corporate power.

Just this week, Representative Kevin McCarthy, the House minority leader, argued in a New York Times op-ed article that cryptocurrencies and the networks they create could provide an answer to the privacy scandals facing the internet giants.

Mr. Trump's acting chief of staff, Mick Mulvaney, has been a vocal advocate of Bitcoin in the past.

This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

PHOTO: Steven Mnuchin (PHOTOGRAPH BY ANNA MONEYMAKER/THE NEW YORK TIMES)

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XR8-WSG1-DY0W-426B-00000-00Trump administration weighs bringing antitrust case against Facebook2019-12-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:27ZLexisNexisNEWSTrump administration weighs bringing antitrust case against FacebookTim PearceWashington, D.C.FULL TEXT

The Trump administration is considering suing Facebook for antitrust violations over the way the tech company's multiple platforms interact.

Facebook controls a variety of apps including Instagram, Messenger, and WhatsApp. The Federal Trade Commission is considering suing the tech giant over how its apps integrate and work with competitors, according to the Wall Street Journal.

A majority of the five-member FTC board must vote for an injunction to be brought against Facebook before action is taken. Commission regulators may choose to stop or undo some of the integration between the apps, charging the integration as anti-competitive.

The regulators may also seek to undo some of the apps' integration to make them easier to split into separate companies should the FTC decide to break up Facebook later. Facebook has consistently denied allegations that its business practices violate the FTC's regulations on competition.

An antitrust lawsuit against Facebook may signal more aggressive moves by the Trump administration into other big tech companies, as well. Google and Amazon may also become subjects of FTC lawsuits and investigations.

The Department of Justice is investigating online platforms for allegedly abusing consumers' data and potentially blocking competitors' access to that data unfairly.

Photo Caption:The logo for Facebook appears on screens at the Nasdaq MarketSite, in New York's Times Square, Thursday, March 29, 2018.

urn:contentItem:5W4D-CP91-DXH2-60BD-00000-00Trump Admin To Brief Lawmakers On Iran Threats; Pentagon Up Military Plans For Iran; Trump Order Effectively Bars Huawei Sales In U.S.; Military Leaders Suspend Talks with Protesters for 72 Hours; Trump Order Effectively Bars Huawei Sales in U.S.; Alabama Adopts Most Restrictive Abortion Law in U.S.; ; White House Rejects Democrats Requests for Documents; Former Militant Works to Discourage Radicalization; Plant-Based Burgers. Aired 1-2a ET2019-05-16T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:27ZLexisNexisCNN NEWSROOM1:00 AM ESTJosh ConstineNEWSInternational051618CN.V11Trump Admin To Brief Lawmakers On Iran Threats; Pentagon Up Military Plans For Iran; Trump Order Effectively Bars Huawei Sales In U.S.; Military Leaders Suspend Talks with Protesters for 72 Hours; Trump Order Effectively Bars Huawei Sales in U.S.; Alabama Adopts Most Restrictive Abortion Law in U.S.; ; White House Rejects Democrats Requests for Documents; Former Militant Works to Discourage Radicalization; Plant-Based Burgers. Aired 1-2a ETNick Watt, Samantha Vinograd, Sherisse Pham, Dianne Gallagher, Areva Martin, Jim Acosta, Jim Sciutto, Clare Sebastian, Rosemary Church

U.S. lawmakers push the Trump Administration for specifics why exactly the hardline on Iran. Donald Trump escalates tensions with China effectively banning Huawei from doing business in the United States. The head of Sudan's Transitional Military Council suspends talks with opposition leaders for 72 hours until there is an appropriate climate for completing an agreement. President Donald Trump signed an Executive Order that basically bars Huawei sales in the United States. Alabama Governor Kay Ivey adopts most restrictive abortion law in the United States. Congressional Democrats are fuming over White House refusal to turn over requested documents. On Wednesday, a White House attorney formerly rejected the committee's requests for documents from dozens of individuals. A former Islamic militant now using his experience to discourage other young men from becoming terrorists. Plant-based burgers have found a recipe for success. And investors want a bite of the action.

[01:00:00] NICK WATT, CNN INTERNATIONAL ANCHOR: Hello and thanks for joining us. I'm Nick Watt and you're watching CNN NEWSROOM. Ahead this hour, lots of tough talk but so far few details to back it up. U.S. lawmakers push the Trump Administration for specifics why exactly the hardline on Iran.

Plus, blast Donald Trump escalates tensions with China by targeting its biggest name in tech. Huawei is now effectively banned from doing business in the United States. And world leaders and tech executives team up to fight extremism online but the U.S. refuses to sign on.

Donald Trump might now be turning to Switzerland as a potential back- channel negotiator to ease growing tensions with Iran. Mr. Trump will meet in the coming days with the Swiss president who might help Mr. Trump who says he wants to talk to Tehran. The U.S. State Department meanwhile, citing an imminent threat from Iran and it's proxies ordering all non-emergency workers to leave Iraq from the embassy in Baghdad and the consulate in Erbil.

Many in Congress are demanding answers, details about those alleged threats from Iran that spurred the U.S. military buildup in the region. The Trump administration is scheduled to brief top lawmakers in the day ahead and more now on the Pentagon's planning from CNN's Barbara Starr.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BARBARA STARR, CNN PENTAGON CORRESPONDENT: Updated military options for possible war against Iran include detailed destruction of the regime's massive missile inventory and air defenses before moving to attack nuclear sites. It would take months of buildup and more than 100,000 U.S. troops fighting from the air, land, and sea according to U.S. officials.

That option has been briefed to senior officials including John Bolton, the National Security Adviser, a longtime Iran hawk. But would President Trump who wants to reduce overseas troop levels take the U.S. to war against Iran? DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We have not planned for that. Hopefully, we're not going to have to plan for that.

STARR: The immediate focus gets Iran to back off from what the Pentagon believes is a plan to possibly attack U.S. forces in the region. But so far, the U.S. offering little to no public evidence.

COL. CEDRIC LEIGHTON (RET.), CNN MILITARY ANALYST: What makes me skeptical is the fact that a lot of the intelligence that has been revealed so far seems to be very normal. The red line would have to be either an actual attack or no kidding, actual information that they are about to commit an attack.

STARR: All this as a top British General, the Deputy Commander in Iraq publicly expressed his skepticism.

MAJ. GEN. CHRISTOPHER GHIKA, BRITISH ARMY: Am I concerned about the danger, no not really.

STARR: In an extraordinary statement the U.S. pushed back saying the general's views run counter to the identified credible threats. Iran supreme leader insists his country does not want war.

AL KHAMENEI, SUPREME LEADER, IRAN: There won't be any war with the help of God. We don't seek war.

STARR: U.S. officials are adamant that the threat is very real. Some U.S. diplomats have now been ordered out of Iraq but still no word on what might have caused damage, five to ten-foot holes in the holes of four tankers in the Gulf. Barbara Starr, CNN the Pentagon.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WATT: And as for that blast British general we heard from in Barbara Starr's report, the British government seems to be backtracking on his dismissal of increased threats from Iran. U.S. officials say the British government knows he was wrong and they acknowledge the heightened threat level.

Samantha Vinograd is a CNN National Security Analyst. She joins me now from New York. Now, Sam, the State Department announced Wednesday they're going to pull all non-essential diplomatic staff out of Baghdad and Senator Bob Menendez had something to say about that. Let's just take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. BOB MENENDEZ (D-NJ): There are only two reasons for ordering their departure. We have credible intelligence that our people are at risk or in preparation for military action in Iran.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

WATT: So which do you think it is? Is the really credible intelligence of threats or is the U.S. preparing for war or both? SAMANTHA VINOGRAD, CNN NATIONAL SECURITY ANALYST: Well, I actually don't think the options are mutually exclusive. It is entirely possible that there is increased threat reporting against our personnel in Iraq and that the United States is seriously considering military action in Iran or enhanced military action against Iranian proxies in Iraq and in the region.

[01:05:13] But there's a pretty simple way to answer this question with respect to Congress. The intelligence chiefs and military planners can go and brief the United States Congress. They actually have a legal responsibility to do so with respect to what this increased threat reporting is against our assets in Iraq.

I serve for a year in Iraq. I saw the Iranian threat front and center. I ducked and covered from Iranian rockets and lost colleagues. This threat is very real and has increased and decreased at various points throughout our history in the Iraq theater.

So what needs to happen right now is their Intel chiefs and our military planners need to go to the Hill and explain what's happening. And there are plans reportedly to send the Secretary of State but he's non-intelligence chief any longer and he's not a Defense Department professional either.

WATT: That was going to be my next question. I mean, we have heard that there is going to be some kind of briefing Thursday in Washington for Intel Committee people and Chiefs, but my question was going to be do you think we're going to get any more clarity out of that?

VINOGRAD: I think it really depends who goes. Secretary of State Pompeo should be representing the diplomatic track in the interests of Department of State personnel that were either deployed in Iraq, are leaving Iraq, and/or staying there because they're considered essential staff.

But we have a Director of National Intelligence, we have a Defense Intelligence Agency in the United States which really looks at intelligence related to our military assets deployed overseas. These intelligence professionals should go and brief members of Congress on the threat.

And perhaps if Secretary of State Pompeo wants to be there I think that makes sense. But him going by himself, to me as a former member of the national security team, does not check the box with respect to keeping Congress fully and currently informed on threat assessments.

WATT: And in terms of what's actually going on within the administration, I mean President Trump said on Wednesday there are no divisions within the administration on our policy towards the Middle East. But president Trump is essentially a neo-isolationist and John Bolton is in his ear, and John Bolton is perhaps the most hawkish man in America. How can there not be a division between those two essentially ideologies?

VINOGRAD: Well, to state the obvious, when President Trump says something, you kind of have to assume the opposite is true. So if he said there aren't divisions, it's probably likely that there are. But you know, it is not unusual for there to be divisions within the national security team when it comes to something as dramatic as potential military action in a theater.

I was at the National Security Council when the Syria war started and I can tell you there are a lot of divisions with respect to what we should do and whether we should use military force on the ground in Syria. I wish that we had. It is entirely possible that the Secretary of State is the chief diplomat of the United States does not want to use military force and that he is open to some kind of diplomatic track with Iran.

But John Bolton's job as National Security Adviser is to present all those different views to the president and recommendations from each cabinet member on what to do to counter this alleged increased threat and then for the president to make a decision. John Bolton as national security adviser should not be censoring options from the president. Various National Security Advisors have weighed in with their own recommendation when asked. I've seen National Security Advisors doing it both ways.

So the real question is, is Bolton in some way censoring the content that reaches the president. Is he whispering in his ear and saying that a military option with Iran is the only way to go, or someone like Secretary of State Pompeo who really has been in the lead on this issue, the one who's speaking with the president in saying that maybe it is time to open up some kind of diplomatic contact with the Iranians to try to de-escalate the situation.

WATT: I mean, Trump did tweet on Wednesday. He said, I'm sure that Iran will want to talk soon. But earlier in the week we heard from Ayatollah Khamenei who said we will not talk about the nuclear deal. Such negotiations are poison. Is he going to cave? Will they talk?

VINOGRAD: Having worked on the back-channel negotiations with Iran through the Omanis when they first started, both sides are going to say a lot of things publicly while there is potential -- the possibility or even the possibility that back-channel negotiations are happening right now.

The Iranian regime has egg on its face based upon the fact that they gave something up. They gave up their nuclear program as part of the Iran deal, sanctions were lifted, and then the United States violated that. They have their own domestic politics and hardliners to deal with when it comes to resuming any potential negotiations with the United States.

On the other hand, President Trump assumes that everybody wants to talk to him. At this point, it is unclear to me that the Iranians view the United States as a credible interlocutor. So in addition to the domestic pressure, there's really no -- there's really no likelihood that they trust that even if they sit down with President Trump that he's going to keep his word because he breaks it so often.

So he's hoping perhaps that they talk because things are rising so quickly and escalating so quickly, but I don't know that diplomacy is on the table from the Iranian perspective at this point.

WATT: Sam Vinograd, thank you very much for your insights.

VINOGRAD: Thank you.

WATT: Meanwhile, amid the escalating trade war with China, President Trump is now taking aim at China's leading networking company, Huawei. He signed an executive order barring U.S. companies from buying telecom gear from companies that pose a national security threat. He didn't actually name Huawei.

WATT: And we'll keep sharing these inspiring stories all week and tune in on Sunday morning at 8:00 a.m. in Hong Kong for an hour "CHAMPION FOR CHANGE" special. We will be back in a moment.

WATT: The city of light shining just little bit brighter. Paris celebrating the 130th birthday of the Eiffel Tower. The spectacular laser light show playing out across the structure facade every evening this week.

The tower for the 1889 was the tallest building in the world when it was built in the 1889 World Fair. Now about seven million tours visit the Paris landmark every year.

And the art world is celebrating two record hammer drops. First the most money paid for a work by a living artist. The very much alive Jeff Koons is 64, created his stainless sculpture "Rabbit" in 1986. The whimsical piece just sold at Christie's for more than 91 million dollars.

And a nearly 130-year old work by the French Master Claude Monet just commanded the highest price ever for an impressionist's artwork. $110 million dollars after just eight minutes of bidding at Sotheby's in New York.

Beware, there's some the wordplay ahead. Here it goes. Plant-based burgers have found a recipe for success. And investors want a bite of the action.

CNN's Clare Sebastian gets a taste of this meatless revolution.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

CLARE SEBASTIAN, CNN CORRESPONDENT: The unmistakable sizzle of meat on the grill. The real meat and the Beyond Meat.

NICK BUCCIERO, BAREBURGER: We have our Beyond Burger over here. And we have are beef burger over here. Once you dress them up it's impossible to tell the difference.

SEBASTIAN: At this Bare Burger) restaurant in Manhattan, burgers made some plant protein make up a meaty portion of the sales.

[01:55:01] UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The response has been great. It's been so great in fact that or our menu is now 50 percent vegan.

SEBASTIAN: For first timers it takes a little getting it used to.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Little smoky.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: It's crispy.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: And very good for you. But it doesn't taste like a real burger at all.

SEBASTIAN: Investors though had no trouble taking their first bite. Beyond Meat's beefy IPO scored 160 percent on its first day of trading on May 2nd. The best IPO jump of a major U.S. company since the financial crisis.

Analysts believe it's part of a veggie revolution that is just getting started.

ALEXA HOWARD, EQUITE ANALYST, BERNSTEIN & CO: If it follows the same path that the plant-based beverage market followed, you'd see it growing from roughly $13 billion, $14 billion today up to potentially over $ 40 billion over the next decade.

SEBASTIAN: While Beyond Meat is not yet profitable it's revenues are up more than 130 percent in each of the past three years. And it's expanding into new products categories like meatless sausage.

ETHAN BROWN, CEO, BEYOND MEAT: It's not just vegans and vegetarians that are interested in this. In fact 93 percent of the people that are putting the Beyond Burger in their cart at the nation's largest grocer are also putting in (INAUDIBLE) in their cart. It's a tremendous sign that we are able to grow the business.

SEBASTIAN: Thank you very much. Now the Beyond Burger does have some competition mainly from this one which is the Impossible Burger from Impossible Foods.

That's already on the menu at Burger King which is rolling out the Impossible Whopper. MacDonald is also selling a meatless burger in Germany made by Nestle and Tyson Food is one of the world's biggest meat producers is also set to launch the fake meat.

SEBASTIAN: They both smell like meat. After my first bite well, it felt like eating a burger, just a little less beefy. I quite like them.

I quite like them. They're not exactly like meat but they are something interesting. And I do think this might be a taste of things to come.

Clare Sebastian, CNN -- New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

WATT: You are watching CNN NEWSROOM.

I'm Nick Watt. The news continues on CNN right after this.

ROSEMARY CHURCH, CNN ANCHOR: Hello. And welcome to our viewers joining us from all around the world. I'm Rosemary Church with your next two hours of CNN NEWSROOM. Let's get started.

[02:00:08] U.S. lawmakers and allies --

urn:contentItem:605B-G2R1-JBYT-H1MG-00000-00Trump admin to withdraw protection given to big tech platforms2020-06-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:27ZLexisNexisTrump admin to withdraw protection given to big tech platformsNew Delhi, 2020-06-18 16:04:48


The United States Justice Department kept a proposal on Wednesday to withdraw protection over big tech platforms including Alphabet's Google and Facebook that the companies have enjoyed for decades, a senior officer said as quoted in a Reuters report. This came as yet another move by the Trump administration after the President became enmeshed in a war of words with tech giants.


The goal of the proposal, which is being finalized, is to push tech companies to address criminal content on their platforms such as child exploitation, terrorism or cyberstalking, and boost transparency for users when the outlets take down lawful material, the Justice Department official said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
For the proposal to become law, U.S. lawmakers would need to submit and approve a bill.
"These reforms are targeted at platforms to make certain they are appropriately addressing illegal and exploitive content while continuing to preserve a vibrant, open and competitive internet," Attorney General William Barr said in a statement.
Trump warned the tech platforms of consequences when various social media questioned him, including Twitter and Snapchat on the credibility of his posts. He said that he would propose legislation to dilute the law shielding the tech giants. This came as an extraordinary attempt to regulate outlets where he has been criticized.
Trump said he sought to "remove or change" Section 230 of the 1996 Communications Decency Act, which generally exempts platforms from responsibility for what their users' post and allows them to moderate the content of their sites as they wish.
The Justice Department proposal would mandate platforms to "address" illicit content online, such as the material that violates federal criminal law, the department said.
It would also seek to require the companies to be upfront about content moderation decisions and prevent the big online platforms from invoking Section 230 in antitrust cases.
Facebook policy chief Nick Clegg told reporters that Section 230 enables the company to remove hate speech and that big changes would, "in the end, mean less speech of all kinds appearing online."
The White House welcomed the Justice Department proposal. The spokesperson Judd Deere said: "The president expressly called on DOJ to develop such model legislation in the Executive Order signed recently, and yes, President Trump is pleased to see the department following through."
The Republicans are also mulling on introducing a bill that would allow people to sue social media platforms in case if they feel that their speech has been censored.
In a letter to Google CEO Sundar Pichai, Hawley referenced a dispute with the conservative website The Federalist, saying that Google's threat to demonetize the site because of comments made about Black Lives Matter protests was "profoundly disingenuous."
Hawley said Google sought to hold The Federalist responsible for its readers' comments even though Google's YouTube is not held accountable for comments because of Section 230.
"In short, Google demands minimum oversight for itself, but maximum power over those who use its platform," Hawley wrote, Reuters mentioned in its report.
