Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5TJY-1801-JBYT-H0JH-00000-00Trump begs big tech for free labor to avoid federal hirings2018-10-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:27ZLexisNexisTrump begs big tech for free labor to avoid federal hiringsNew Delhi

New Delhi, Oct. 24 -- The White House wants the nation's big tech companies to make it easier for employees to do a civic "tour of duty" with the government. Another way of putting it: the President needs to bring in temps now that his plan to cheat Federal workers out of their promised 2019 pay raise fell apart.


This latest assault on Federal employees by the White House comes in the form of a meeting held Monday between lawmakers and representatives from several technology companies. According to a report from The Washington Post, the purpose of the gathering was to convince big tech bosses to come up with policies making it easier for employees to take a leave of absence to temporarily work for the government.
According to The Post, White House deputy chief of staff for policy coordination Christopher Liddell said:
The country benefits when patriotic citizens with technical expertise choose to serve at the federal, state or local level.
This statement indicates the Trump administration is framing this as a voluntary civic duty, like picking up litter or voting. But is it really patriotic? Let's take a deeper look
On President Donald Trump's third day in office he signed an executive order freezing pay for Federal employees. It's the kind of move you expect from a new CEO taking the reigns of a company running in the red. Unfortunately, as the President's learned in the time since, the US isn't a business.
It's part business, of course. Capitalism is a large part of what the US is made of, but it's not the entire recipe. So the President's plan, which we assume was simply to get a handle on spending, was effective from a fiscal standpoint (think in terms of quarterly reports). And the move likely motivated lawmakers to consider the country's budgetary concerns under Trump differently, which is a political win.
But, there's an important distinction between the US government and a corporation. Just like the difference between angels and humans - in the Christian bible - only the latter has free will.
If your company makes vodka with your name on it, for example, and your business acumen has led you to a point where you can no longer afford to make vodka with your name on it, you can pivot to another endeavor - like creating a university with your name on it.
In the business world, the only thing holding you back is your imagination - some would argue this is especially true when it comes to dealing with government regulations.
Because, if businesses are the free-willed humans in this analogy, then government represents the angels beholden to the will of their master: in this case, instead of God, the US Constitution.
We can try to run the country like a business, but at the end of the day there are certain protections the people have in place which require the government to spend money, even if it doesn't turn a profit. Just because the President finds a loophole, or a way around spending money on certain budget line-items, it doesn't mean he's doing our nation any favors.
President Trump has a lot of wiggle room when it comes to the machinations of government, but he also has to contend with Federal hiring and pay practices that have evolved over centuries. And, while it may not be a law, he also has an obligation to ensure the government keeps certain promises it's made to one of its most vulnerable populations: veterans. It'll hurt veterans
There have been times throughout our nation's history when the popularity of veterans in the public eye has waxed and waned. Vets who served during the Vietnam conflict, for example, were ostracized by the public in many areas of the country. And there remains a stigma surrounding combat veterans: many people aren't comfortable hiring someone who has been exposed to war for fear we'll "snap."
The US government, however, disproportionately hires military veterans because it's promised to do so. We're told from the earliest days of our basic training that our service will always be remembered and honored by our leaders, and that we'll receive support when its time to reenter the civilian workforce.
Veterans make up more than 30 percent of the Federal workforce. And the Department of Defense employs more US veterans than any other entity, government or civilian, in the world. So, it's not an exaggeration to say that any policies which affect Federal workers directly affect veterans today, and the future prospects for military service members currently on active duty or in the reserves. Who benefits?
Borrowing people from Amazon, Google, or Microsoft is a tourniquet, not a solution. Especially considering that the most important question may be whether these temp workers are going to have access to classified information.
This is an incredibly important question. If the answer is "no" it's obvious this is an attempt to package lowered pay for Federal workers (and less jobs for veterans) as patriotic duty for high-payed tech experts. We already have computer experts working for the government. You don't need a Microsoft employee on site to perform Office upgrades or other similar technology endeavors, for example.
This wouldn't be any different than threatening to replace workers with robots. The result is the same: people who rely on these jobs won't be doing them. Instead, someone who has already won the job lottery by getting hired at one of the largest technology companies in the country gets the work.
What if the answer is yes and it turns out these projects will involve classified information? Then we need to know who will pay for the lengthy background checks for the on-loan workers. Let's assume the government won't. Doing so would defeat the purpose of using temp workers instead of hiring a veteran or other qualified candidate from the job pool because it would cost more.
That just leaves big tech to pay for those clearances. And that means there are going to be strings attached whether the government can see it or not. It's like inviting a fox into your hen house because it knows more about eggs than you.
The bottom line is that the White House needs to keep its promises, and protect our interests, even if that means it'll have to find other ways to pay for Trump's tax cuts.
Bringing in experts on loan, instead of properly staffing the Federal government, won't fix the gaping holes that already exist in this administration's science and technology departments. But it will hurt veterans.

urn:contentItem:5TJP-D6H1-JCMN-Y1B1-00000-00Trump begs big tech for free labor to avoid federal hirings2018-10-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:27ZLexisNexisTrump begs big tech for free labor to avoid federal hiringsTristan Greene

Oct 23, 2018( TheNextWeb.com: http://thenextweb.com Delivered by Newstex) The White House wants the nation's big tech companies to make it easier for employeesto do a civic 'tour of duty' with the government. Another way of putting it: the President needs to bring in temps now that his plan to cheat Federal workers out of their promised 2019 pay raise fell apart[1]. This latest assault on Federal employees by the White House comes in the form of a meeting held Monday between lawmakers and representatives from several technology companies. According to a report[2] fromThe Washington Post, the purpose of the gathering was to convince big tech bosses to come up with policies making it easier for employees to take a leave of absence to temporarily work for the government.According to The Post,White House deputy chief of staff for policy coordination Christopher Liddellsaid: The country benefits when patriotic citizens with technical expertise choose to serve at the federal, state or local level. This statement indicates the Trump[3] administration is framing this as a voluntary civic duty, like picking up litter or voting.

But is it really patriotic?Let's take a deeper lookOn President Donald Trump's third day in office he signed[4] an executive order freezing pay for Federal employees. It's the kind of move you expect from a new CEO taking the reigns of a company running in the red. Unfortunately, as the President's learned in the time since, the US isn't a business. It's part business, of course. Capitalism is a large part of what the US is made of, but it's not the entire recipe. So the President's plan, which we assume was simply to get a handle on spending, was effective from a fiscal standpoint (think in terms of quarterly reports). And the move likely motivated lawmakers to consider the country's budgetary concerns under Trump differently, which is a political win. But, there's an important distinction between the US government and a corporation. Just like the difference between angels and humans - in the Christian bible - only the latter has free will. If your company makes vodka with your name on it, for example, and your business acumen[5] has led you to a point where you can no longer afford to make vodka with your name on it, you can pivot to another endeavor — like creating a university with your name on it. In the business world, the only thing holding you back is your imagination - some would argue this is especially true when it comes to dealing with government regulations. Because, ifbusinesses are the free-willedhumans in this analogy, then government represents the angels beholden to the will of their master: in this case, instead of God, the US Constitution. We can try to run the country like a business, but at the end of the day there are certain protections the people have in place which require the government to spend money, even if it doesn't turn a profit. Just because the President finds a loophole, or a way around spending money on certain budget line-items, it doesn't mean he's doing our nation any favors. President Trump has a lot of wiggle room when it comes to the machinations of government, but he also has to contend with Federal hiring and pay practices that have evolved over centuries. And, while it may not be a law, he also has an obligation to ensure the government keeps certain promises it's made to one of its most vulnerable populations: veterans.It'll hurt veteransThere have been times throughout our nation's history when the popularity of veterans in the public eye has waxed and waned. Vets who served during the Vietnam conflict, for example, were ostracized by the public in many areas of the country. And there remains a stigma surrounding combat veterans: many people aren't comfortable hiring someone who has been exposed to war for fear we'll 'snap.' The US government, however, disproportionately hires[6] military veterans because it's promised to do so. We're told from the earliest days of our basic training that our service will always be remembered and honored by our leaders, and that we'll receive support when its time to reenter the civilian workforce. Veterans make up more than 30 percent of the Federal workforce. And the Department of Defense[7] employs more US veterans than any other entity, government or civilian, in the world. So, it's not an exaggeration to say that any policies which affect Federal workers directly affect veterans today, and the future prospects for military service members currently on active duty or in the reserves.Who benefits?Borrowing people from Amazon, Google, or Microsoft is a tourniquet, not a solution. Especially considering that the most important question may be whether these temp workers are going to have access toclassified information. This is an incredibly important question. If the answer is 'no' it's obvious this is an attempt to package lowered pay for Federal workers (and less jobs for veterans) as patriotic duty for high-payed tech experts. We already have computer experts working for the government. You don't need aMicrosoft employee on site to perform Office upgrades or other similar technology endeavors, for example. This wouldn't be any different than threatening to replace workers with robots. The result is the same: people who rely on these jobs won't be doing them. Instead, someone who has already won the job lottery by getting hired at one of the largest technology companies in the country gets the work. What if the answer is yes and it turns out these projects will involve classified information? Then we need to know who will pay for the lengthy background checks for the on-loan workers. Let's assume the government won't. Doing so would defeat the purpose of using temp workers instead of hiring a veteran or other qualified candidate from the job pool because it would cost more. That just leaves big tech to pay for those clearances. And that means there are going to be strings attached whether the government can see it or not. It's like inviting a fox into your hen house because it knows more about eggs than you. The bottom line is that the White House needs to keep its promises, and protect our interests, even if that means it'll have to find other ways to pay for Trump's tax cuts. Bringing in experts on loan, instead of properly staffing the Federal government, won't fix the gaping holes[8] that already exist in this administration's science and technology departments. But it will hurt veterans. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5WJ0-VX31-F12B-J49B-00000-00TRUMPBIG TECHVERSUS2019-07-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:27ZLexisNexisWORLDPg. A019TRUMPBIG TECHVERSUS

US President gathers conservative groups for social media summit, snubbing ?biased? social media titans

US President Donald Trump is gathering conservative groups at the White House this week for a ?(EURO)oesummit?(EURO) on social media that will prominently snub the tech titans who run big platforms on Facebook, Twitter and Google.

It?(EURO)(TM)s a sharp contrast to earlier days in Trump?(EURO)(TM)s tenure when tech executives were occasional celebrity guests at the White House, serving as a fresh indication of the president?(EURO)(TM)s escalating battle with Big Tech.

Now, Trump regularly accuses the big social media platforms of suppressing conservative voices. He has suggested the companies may be acting illegally and should be sued by US regulators.

White House spokesman Judd Deere said the White House conference would bring together ?(EURO)oedigital leaders for a robust conversation on the opportunities and challenges of today?(EURO)(TM)s online environment?(EURO).

But Google, Facebook and Twitter weren?(EURO)(TM)t invited, their representatives confirmed.

Among the conservative organisations expected to participate in the White House meeting: Turning Point USA; PragerU, short for Prager University, which puts out short videos with a conservative perspective on politics or economics; and the Washington think tank Heritage Foundation.

Trump and some supporters have long accused Silicon Valley companies of being biased against them. Accusations commonly levelled against the platforms include anti-religious bias, a tilt against those opposed to abortion and censorship of conservative political views.

Representatives for Facebook, Google and Twitter declined to comment specifically on the meeting. But the Internet Association, the industry?(EURO)(TM)s major trade group representing Facebook, Google and dozens of other companies, said the internet ?(EURO)oeoffers the most open and accessible form of communication available today?(EURO).

Its members?(EURO)(TM) platforms ?(EURO)oedon?(EURO)(TM)t have a political ideology or political bias,?(EURO) the group?(EURO)(TM)s president and CEO Michael Beckerman said in a statement. He added that the companies ?(EURO)oesucceed and grow by building a broad user base regardless of party affiliation or political perspectives?(EURO).

The White House conference offers Trump a chance to play to his conservative base in the lead-up to the 2020 election.

Trump has played to conservative concerns about bias on other issues. In March, he signed an executive order requiring US colleges to protect free speech on their campuses or risk losing federal research funding. The order cheered those who said universities were attempting to silence some conservative students and speakers. But critics called the order unnecessary.

The president himself was dealt a setback yesterday in his legal battle against Twitter. A federal appeals court in New York City ruled the president can?(EURO)(TM)t ban critics from his Twitter account.

The conference raised questions about whether Trump would use the forum to signal tough actions against the big companies in the areas of competition and privacy.

Big tech companies already are under closer scrutiny than ever by regulators and in Congress following a stream of scandals including Facebook?(EURO)(TM)s lapses opening the personal data of millions of users to Trump?(EURO)(TM)s 2016 campaign. A bipartisan push for new data privacy legislation has emerged in Congress. Regulators at the Justice Department and the Federal Trade Commission are pursuing antitrust investigations of Facebook, Google, Apple and Amazon. The House Judiciary Committee has opened a bipartisan probe of the tech giants?(EURO)(TM) market dominance.

Trump said last week on Fox News that Google, Facebook and Twitter ?(EURO)oeare fighting me hard right now?(EURO).

Asked whether tech companies may be acting illegally and whether the Justice Department should determine that, Trump replied, ?(EURO)oeWell, they could be and I don?(EURO)(TM)t want to even say whether or not they?(EURO)(TM)re doing something, but I will tell you, there are a lot of people that want us ... to take action against Facebook and against Twitter and, frankly, against Amazon.?(EURO)

Trump told Fox Business Network?(EURO)(TM)s Maria Bartiromo last month that he doesn?(EURO)(TM)t know if what the companies are doing is illegal but added: ?(EURO)oeI tell you what, they should be sued because of what?(EURO)(TM)s happening with the bias.?(EURO) ?(EURO)"AP

urn:contentItem:5WGF-0KN1-JCMN-Y4YF-00000-00Trump Blames Liberals For Homelessness In U.S. Cities In Rambling Monologue2019-07-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:27ZLexisNexisTrump Blames Liberals For Homelessness In U.S. Cities In Rambling MonologueAmy Russo

Jul 02, 2019( The Huffington Post: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Play Video[1] In a nearly three-minute meandering monologue, President Donald Trump[2] described U.S. cities as hellscapes riddled with filth, blaming liberals for their supposed demise.The speech came near the end of Trump's Fox News[3] interview in Japan that aired Monday night.Shifting topics from the regulation of big tech to the cleanliness of cities, host Tucker Carlson[4] said places like Osaka and Tokyo are 'very different from our cities' because there's 'no graffiti, no one going to the bathroom on the street' and 'you don't see junkies.'He took aim in particular at New York, San Francisco and Los Angeles.Trump replied that Carlson was describing 'a phenomenon that started two years ago' in U.S. cities, saying 'it's disgraceful' and that he's 'looking at it very seriously.'He later asserted that 'they're usually sanctuary cities run by liberal people, and the states are run by very liberal people.''Police officers are getting sick just by walking the beat,' Trump said, adding, 'The people living there are living in hell, too, although some of them have mental problems where they don't even know they're living that way.

In fact, perhaps they like living that way.'Though Trump did not use the word 'homelessness,' outlets includingThe New York Times[5], The Washington Post[6]and Fox News[7] itself understood his comments as a reference to people living on the streets.Trump said he 'may intercede,' but provided no specifics on his efforts to combat the issue.'We may do something to get that whole thing cleaned up,' he said. 'It's inappropriate. Now, we have to take the people and do something, we have to do something, and we're really not very equipped as a government to be doing that kind of work.'According toDepartment of Housing and Urban Development data released in 2018[8], the national rate of homelessness has actually trended downward for the past decade.From 2007 to 2018, it dropped by 15%.However, major U.S. cities are indeed struggling with homelessness. According to point-in-time counts[9] of the homeless population conducted annually, San Francisco has seen a 17% increase in homelessness over the past two years, while Los Angeles saw a 16% jump within just the past year.A December 2018HUD report[10] showed that in New York City, homelessness increased nearly 3% from 2017 to 2018.Trump implied in his interview that he had solved homelessness in Washington, D.C., at the start of his presidency, but provided no evidence to support that claim.A May 2019 report[11] from the Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments, a nonprofit organization of area leaders, counted nearly 10,000 homeless people in the city. This article originally appeared on The Huffington Post https://www.huffpost.com/entry/trump-homelessness-us-cities_n_5d1b991ae4b03d611643424e?ncid=txtlnkusaolp00000603 [ 1]:   https://www.youtube.com/embed/mRQW675j6dM?rel=0 [ 2]:   https://www.huffpost.com/news/topic/donald-trump [ 3]:   https://www.huffpost.com/news/topic/fox-news [ 4]:   https://www.huffpost.com/news/topic/tucker-carlson [ 5]:   https://www.nytimes.com/2019/07/02/us/politics/trump-homeless.html [ 6]:   https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2019/07/02/trump-paints-dark-picture-homelessness-cities-we-may-intercede/?utm_term=.b12d91f3ca34 [ 7]:   https://www.foxnews.com/politics/trump-tucker-exclusive-interview-homelessness [ 8]:   https://endhomelessness.org/homelessness-in-america/homelessness-statistics/state-of-homelessness-report/ [ 9]:   https://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-trump-homeless-los-angeles-20190702-story.html [ 10]:   https://files.hudexchange.info/resources/documents/2018-AHAR-Part-1.pdf [ 11]: file:///Users/arusso/Downloads/2019_PIT_report_FINAL_update.pdf

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5MBX-2931-JBHT-D1GK-00000-00Trump Blasts Boeing Deal; Trump's First 100 Days; Biden To Run In 2020; Pentagon Hides $125B Waste; Dershowitz Blasts Dem Pick to Lead DNC;2016-12-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:27ZLexisNexisTrump Blasts Boeing Deal; Trump's First 100 Days; Biden To Run In 2020; Pentagon Hides $125B Waste; Dershowitz Blasts Dem Pick to Lead DNC;LanhamFULL TEXT

NEIL CAVUTO, FBN HOST: But a quick footnote on the Russell, it has had double the gains of the Dow close to 19 percent year to date. Trish Regan, to you!

TRISH REGAN, FBN HOST: All right. Thanks so much, Neil.

President-Elect Donald Trump taking on government waste today, blasting Boeing for wasting taxpayer dollars on a new presidential plane, Air Force One.

I am Trish Regan. Welcome everyone to "The Intelligence Report".

The ultimate businessman putting Boeing on notice, calling for the cancellation of the new Air Force One tweeting that Boeing costs are out of control., he elaborated on that a short time ago to reporters. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, (R) PRESIDENT-ELECT: It's going to be over $4 billion. It's for Air Force One program. And, I think it's ridiculous. I think Boeing is doing a little bit of a number. We want Boeing to make a lot of money but not that much money.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

REGAN: All right. We've got more on Trump's push to rein in government spending and what it's going to mean for the likes of Boeing and other companies. You know, you think about some of these companies that have been given blank checks for decades, things might change.

Now, amid the Boeing controversy, Mr. Trump is meeting with advisers today at Trump Tower. You're looking at a live picture coming into us right now, a lot of people going in and out. He's still searching for a Secretary of State.

Exxon CEO Rex Tillerson met him at Trump Tower and remains a contender for the job alongside Mitt Romney, Rudy Giuliani and a new one John Huntsman.

Former Ronald Reagan Attorney General, Edwin Meese, is here. He's going to going to join me in just a moment with his predictions for Trump's cabinet.

And on the other side, you've got the Democrats that seem to be spiraling out of control here. Right now they're poised to pick a radical, left-wing extremist, Keith Ellison, to lead their party. Has this party not learned anything from the election?

The esteemed Alan Dershowitz is here with why the Democrats just don't get it and why Ellison a man who has ties to the nation of Islam and the Muslim brotherhood is about as bad as it can get for the Democratic Party.

But first, let's head out to Trump Tower. Blake Burman is joining us right now with the latest on the hunt for our Secretary of State. Blake?

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS: Hi there, Trish! And it's been a busy one here at Trump Tower, actually a first today you just talked about it a little bit. After the president-elect sent out that tweet saying that the Air Force One order should be canceled. He actually came down to the lobby himself to speak with reporters, briefly talked about it saying that that situation is out of control, in his words.

Most of the action now taking place upstairs in the tower as the interviews continue and the one that is seeming to gain most of the attention is the ExxonMobil CEO, Rex Tillerson. He met with the president-elect. Tillerson has already come and gone.

That Secretary of State search appears to be expanding the Trump transition folks, though, when they were talking about it today, seemed to pump the brakes at least on the notion or at least the thinking that many of the people attached to the job are, indeed, interviewing for the job.

They also say that the president-elect likes to seek advice from many other people that he speaks with and talks to here at Trump Tower.

By the way, Mr. Trump is set to leave the tower here in a couple hours. He will head to North Carolina for the second stop of what he is calling his "Thank You" tour. Trish back to you.

REGAN: That's right. We'll be watching, right here on Fox Business tonight. Thank you so much, Blake.

For more on the transition team, I am joined by Former Attorney General under Ronald Reagan, Edwin Meese, and Tom Fitton, the President of Judicial Watch. Good to see both of you.

First of all, Mr. Meese, lots to talk about here today, but I'd like to know what you think about as far of the appointments Donald Trump has made.

EDWIN MEESE, FORMER ATTORNEY GENERAL UNDER REAGAN: I think they've been absolutely excellent. I was particularly impressed with Jeff Sessions being one of the first appointments. I've known Jeff for a long time. We worked together in the Department of Justice when I was attorney general.

He was an outstanding attorney general of Alabama, he's been an outstanding senator, and I can't think you could do better than Jeff Sessions. Likewise I think all of the other appointments have been excellent as well. Ms. Devos, Ben Carson, I could go down the list. Every one of them has just been first class, and I think America should be very proud of what Mr. Trump has done so far.

REGAN: Mr. Meese, do you anticipate a lot of pushback from Democrats? I mean, we're already hearing rumblings, there are a lot of folks out there that are going to try and make life difficult anyway, but a lot of them specifically are taking issue with Jeff Sessions. What do you say to that?

MEESE: Well, I would hope that the Democrats would rise above this politicization. You know, I wish they would treat the nominees by President-Elect Trump the way the Republicans treated the nominees that were put forth by President Obama. And I think fairness would indicate particularly with Jeff Sessions. He's got an impeccable record.

And this phony idea that somehow there's something wrong with his views on race are absolutely untrue. We're totally disproved years ago, have totally been proved by his record ever since.

REGAN: What about Mitt Romney? What are your thoughts on Mitt Romney?

MEESE: Well, Mr. Romney is, has been a very good member of the Republican Party. I don't know enough about him, frankly, to really render an opinion.

REGAN: A lot of people feel like he hasn't exactly been loyal, perhaps that's the understatement of the year, but, you know, he came out pretty aggressively against Donald Trump in the weeks and days before that election. It's not clear that he even voted for him. So some are scratching their heads saying why on earth is this guy being considered for the top job? Do you think, Mr. Meese, there are better contenders there? They're talking about Jon Huntsman, possibly Mr. Tillerson from Exxon, and there some others on that list including Rudy Giuliani who's been there from the beginning.

MEESE: Well, and you've left out one that I think is one of the best candidates, and that's John Bolton. John Bolton worked with me in the Justice Department. He was outstanding. He was the assistant attorney general for Legislative Liaison. He was the head of the civil division. And I think he would be also and excellent prospect.

But, of course, it's really up to Mr. Trump on these issues, and I'm sure he'll make as good a choice for Secretary's of States as he has done in the other appointments.

REGAN: I want to come back to you, Mr. Meese on Donald Trump, but let me go to over Tom for a moment because I know that you were both involved today in a panel called the First Hundred Days, the anti-corruption agenda.

You know, some of the things that I've heard and seen and witnessed over the last several years and some of the things that have come out concerning the potential pay-to-play scandal with the Clinton Foundation, Tom, have been quite concerning. How do we make sure that there is no corruption in government? How do we ensure transparency? What are your ideas for that right now in this new administration?

TOM FITTON, JUDICIAL WATCH PRESIDENT: Well, it needs to be a priority of the president, and it needs to be a priority of his appointees. Jeff Sessions is a rule of law guy, a law and order appointee. I expect he'll enforce the rule of law on immigration and matters like that on the Clinton corruption issues. They should consider a special prosecutor or in the least get the thumb, the political thumb off the scales of justice. Get politics out of the Clinton investigation and let it go forward because politics is preventing .

REGAN: OK. So you want to see this investigation continue, because there's been sort of a hands-off approach, at least most recently, where it doesn't seem as though we're going to see a whole lot in the way of an investigation for Hillary Clinton and the foundation. You want that to change, Tom?

FITTON: Yeah, I think it has to continue. Mr. Trump promised that there would be a serious investigation, and Jeff Sessions is, I think, the prime candidate to make sure it's done. And it's not doing anything unusual, it's just allowing the FBI to do its job and getting the Justice Department to stop obstructing the FBI investigation. Supposedly, the Clinton Foundation, the FBI can't get interviews, can't get subpoenas, can't get grand juries. That's out of the ordinary and its needs to stop.

REGAN: And yet, Ed, you know, many feel like that's going backwards, right? There are so much that's got to be done. We've got to get this economy going again. How do we deal with the Clinton Foundation if there's some bad stuff there and, you know, there certainly some evidence that Tom has been instrumental in bringing forward that suggests there could have been some questionable ethics involved. You know, you don't want to let that go, but at the same time we've got a lot to do in terms of getting the country back on its feet again. Where do you come out, Ed?

MEESE: Well, I think we ought to handle the Clinton Foundation investigation like we would any other case, and that is that whatever evidence is there that calls for the investigation and Tom has done an excellent job and the judicial watch is just, it's amazing to me. They've gotten more information than either the federal government or the news media, quite frankly, about what's going on in some of these conflicts and some of these corruption cases.

REGAN: Yeah. They've been out in front of it, for sure.

MEESE: So I think we got to follow the rule of law, have an honest, legitimate, non-politicized investigation and then see where the chips fall after all the facts are out.

REGAN: All right. Well, and I guess you're counting on Jeff Sessions to do it. Ed and Tom, thank you very much. Good to have you guys here today, appreciate it.

All right, on the other side of the aisle, you've got Vice President Joe Biden saying he's running for president in 2020. He's going to be 78. I mean, I'm no ageist or anything, but this guy has been around a while, right? So what it tells you? Really, is that when it comes to the left, they've got no new blood. I mean, take a listen here, I want you to hear party leader Nancy Pelosi who has led the Democratic caucus for the last 14 years. Here she is way back when.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NANCY PELOSI, HOUSE MINORITY LEADER: Well, I don't think that people want a new direction. Our values unify us, and our values are about supporting America's working families. That is one that everyone is in agreement on.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

REGAN: Actually, that was from just this past Sunday, but she's been saying that over and over and over again. I mean, that's been the whole theme, right? Working families? But you know what, working families they sure don't feel like they've been supported in the last eight years, which is why the Democrats lost, isn't it?

Joining me right now, Washington Examiner Senior Political Columnist, Tim Carney. Tim, good to see you.

What's happening to the Democratic Party? Where are the new faces?

TIM CARNEY, WASHINGTON EXAMINER: Well, they've known for a while that they had a shallow bench. That was one of the concerns coming into the 2016 election, and, in fact, they had trouble recruiting some good candidates. But the consolation prize was going to be that for four or eight years they had the White House. They'd be able to build up a bench through cabinet jobs, through just the power of the presidency. Well, that's not there, and now they're in the real trouble, and as Nancy Pelosi said, most Democrats don't think they need a new direction, two thirds of the congressional Democrats voted her for minority leader. Most of the primary voters voted Hillary Clinton to be the nominee, so they seem to be happy continuing on the path that they're on which has led them to a minority.

REGAN: To a certain extent, isn't this a kind of cronyism? I mean the fact that they put Clinton in the spot that she got when -- they had, by the way, they like Sanders and I'm not socialist I'm no Sanders fan, but my goodness, he really started to captivate people. They had Joe Biden.

CARNEY: Yeah.

REGAN: . by the way who really, you know, and obviously, he went through a personal tragedy, but he also suffered, of course, as a result of the party saying, no, it's her time. This is her opportunity, we're going to get the first woman president, and, you know, the reality is she just isn't that good a candidate.

CARNEY: No, and she -- everybody knew that she was not going to be liked. And if they're keeping Pelosi in there as well, to me it's a sign that they're not actually that interested in building a majority that it's protecting what they have going. One way we put in an examiner editorials maybe they elected Pelosi because they wanted to save space for liberals there on Capitol Hill, that each space is not away to hear outside ideas, it's what .

REGAN: Yeah, no, and look .

CARNEY: It's happening on College campuses and happening on the hill.

REGAN: I hear you. And she's from a very wealthy part of San Francisco, a very wealthy woman herself, you know, in part family money there. And I think has grown increasingly distant from sort of the core Democratic voter who may be out there in the Midwest and is dealing with the hard times of jobs moving overseas.

And so, until you start to tap into that, you know what, you're going to continue losing, and that's what we saw in this election cycle. It looks like they really aren't helping themselves as much either with the likes of Keith Ellison which we're going to talk about in a minute.

Tim Carney, good to have you here, thank you very much.

All right, everyone, Donald Trump making good on his vow to take aim at government waste, he's going after Boeing for what he calls out of control spending on the new Air Force One plane. Four billion dollars, is what we're talking about, way too much, says Donald Trump. Boeing is being put on notice, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: The plane is totally out of control. It's going to be over $4 billion. It's for Air Force One program. And I think it's ridiculous.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: All right, you know, just this morning -- it was an interesting morning I can tell you, the President-Elect Donald Trump was out there criticizing a government contract with Boeing claiming it's going to cost taxpayers $4 billion to build the next Air Force One plane. Trump originally tweeted that he would cancel the deal, and now he's doubling down on his comments. Take a listen to him just a short time ago at Trump Tower.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: The plane is totally out of control. It's going to be over $4 billion. It's for Air Force One program and I think it's ridiculous. I think Boeing is doing a little bit of a number. We want Boeing to make a lot of money but not that much money.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

REGAN: All right, this comes as new report say the State Department buried information that exposed $125 billion in government waste. According to this study, the back office bureaucracy at the Pentagon is so overstaffed that it has almost as many people working desk jobs as it does active duty troops.

Joining me right now from Americans for Prosperity, the president of it, Tim Phillips. Good to see you, good to have you here.

TIM PHILLIPS, AMERICANS FOR PROSPERITY, PRESIDENT: Good to be here.

REGAN: How scared do you think Boeing is right now as a result of today's movements?

PHILLIPS: It's good to keep these contractors on their toes, right? I mean, these political leaders, Trump in this case, it's good to see we're going to check every contract. We're going to look at every dollar you spent because it's taxpayer dollars. I think it's a good thing. And I hope it gives pause to everyone out there doing business with the government. You've got stay within cost to do your job.

REGAN: Well, I'll tell you, I don't think Boeing knows what to make of this.

PHILLIPS: Right.

REGAN: They issued a statement today, let me just share it with the viewers. It's basically what you call a big old nothing statement. I read it and kind of laughed because they're not actually even addressing the elephant in the room. They say, "We are currently under contract for $170 million to help determine the capability of these complex military aircraft that serve the unique requirements of the President of the United States," and they go on to say, "We look forward to working with the U.S. Air Force on subsequent phases of the program allowing us to deliver the best planes to the President, the best value of the American tax payer."

So they're basically saying, hey, guess what? I mean we work for the government, we're working on this plane, and we hope to give you the best value. But they, they don't really address what's at issue here which is this concern that costs .

PHILLIPS: Right.

REGAN: . have gotten completely out of control. You watch this, what are some of the most egregious examples?

PHILLIPS: Well, we have debt at $20 trillion, so it's across the board, but it seems like contractors see the initial contract just as a starting point for negotiation, right? They get that authorization, maybe it's a billion or two, and it starts skyrocketing. We see this across the board whether it's export-import bank which has gone dramatically over, over the years or just bureaucracy after bureaucracy. But it's good to hold these guys accountable on the consistent basis to the original terms of the contract. In the private sector, that's what's happening, that's what government should do.

REGAN: You're Boeing. Can we show shares of Boeing right now to the viewer? Let's take a look at the stock price it was down about 1 percent .

PHILLIPS: Yeah.

REGAN: . in the pre-market and was stumbling a bit throughout the margin (ph) of the market has changed course, and we're now in positive territory overall for the Dow.

Nonetheless, you see Boeing still trading off about a tenth of a percent. You know, it used to be, basically, with these big government contracts it always has been, you know, you kind of get free rein, you walk in near .

PHILLIPS: Right.

REGAN: . if you're Boeing, I mean who else is going to build Air Force One?

PHILLIPS: Right.

REGAN: And so, you can almost charge whatever you want. Have that changed?

PHILLIPS: Not enough. Right now they're getting ready to have a lame duck session wrap up. They're going to have thousands of special interest exemptions in the tax code for group after group whether it's bourbon distillery folks or whether it's horse racing folks, they all get their chunks because of the special interest groups that they pay for, basically. And that's got to be stopped. We need lower flatter rates across the board, and when you actually get a government contract, it should be openly bid on, and you have to have live up to the terms of the original contract.

REGAN: Hey, let me quickly ask you, $125 billion .

PHILLIPS: Yeah, and hidden away. They buried this report $125 billion, over just five years. Internal report, they asked for it, they paid for it. Imagine, Trish, I'm going to say paid for this report. And it looks like they buried it, have it do anything about it because they're afraid about .

REGAN: Can you say, you say good for Trump on exposing all of this stuff, what do you mean by that?

PHILLIPS: I think that political officials, elected leaders, ought to be willing to hold every single federal contractor accountable to stay within cost. The private sector does that, it's time the government does it, so good for them in this regard.

REGAN: This is what people liked about him, they like .

PHILLIPS: Yeah.

REGAN: . the idea that they were getting a businessman who would come to office and say, look, let's get some accountability here. Good to see you, Tim.

PHILLIPS: Absolutely.

REGAN: thank you so much.

All right, Democrats seemingly poised to select Keith Ellison to lead the DNC after Howard Dean drops out of the running. OK, let me just make sure I got this right because you've got a party that's been abandoned by white, blue collar voters and in response it wants to appoint a radical and extreme left-wing ideologue with ties to Louis Farrakhan? Legal legend Alan Dershowitz is in the house. He says this is totally nuts, stay with me. See you here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: Well, Democrats seem poised anyway at this point to pick a far-left extremist for the DNC, Keith Ellison, a congressman from Minnesota. He may be heading out to the DNC now that Howard Dean has pulled out. But after the party was beaten badly and we're talking very badly at the polls and lost of the support of white working class Americans, why on earth are they after picking someone like Ellison? I mean this is someone who at one time supported and worked with the nation of Islam and Louis Farrakhan. Here's Farrakhan, the guy he was working alongside just a year ago blasting white people. Watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LOUIS FARRAKHAN, NATION OF ISLAM, GROUP LEADER: Everywhere the white man - - his nature drove him to kill. Kill the brown. Kill the red. Kill the yellow. Kill my own white brother. And kill the black and make sure that the black never rise again.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

REGAN: All right, joining me right now on the prospect of Ellison at the DNC, famed legal scholar, Alan Dershowitz, the legend himself. Good to say you, good to have you here.

ALAN DERSHOWITZ, HARVARD LAW PROFESSOR: Thank you, Trish.

REGAN: You think this is crazy, right, to have somebody like Ellison?

DERSHOWITZ: It's about the dumbest thing among many dumb things the Democrats have done. After losing white, middle class, working class people in the Midwest, you're going to pick somebody who for nine years was associated with a hate America, anti-American, anti-western person? It's just nuts. And they're going to lose a lot of Democrats if they appoint him.

REGAN: They're trying to double down. I mean they clearly were wrong in their approach to this election which they, you know, still don't really want to admit, because for some reason it's about women not supporting women, et cetera, et cetera. People just being misogynistic or this that and the other, but do they just not want to admit it, Alan? I mean, what's going on here? Why would you double down on the strategy that didn't work?

DERSHOWITZ: Well, it's one thing to have lost this election because you couldn't have anticipated how badly the Democrats could do in the Rust Belt in the Midwest. But now that you know that, you pick as leader of the Democratic Party the worst possible person to bring them back.

If I were a Republican strategist and I would given the choice to pick the head of the Democratic National Committee, I'd say pick Ellison. He would be great for the Republicans, and he's going to be great for the Republicans. Already high (inaudible), he was a major contributor to the Democratic Party has said, essentially, don't count on me anymore. He is going to lose many, many Democrats. He's going to lose many pro-Israel Democrats, many pro-American Democrats. Forget about Farrakhan's anti- semitism and the fact that this guy was part of that for years. Do you know what he said at one point to somebody when he was a student at the Minnesota Law School?

REGAN: Tell us.

DERSHOWITZ: He said to somebody who was a woman and Jewish, I can have no respect for you, this is Ellison saying this, not Farrakhan, I can have no respect for you because you're Jewish and you're a woman. And as a woman, you shouldn't be working, you should be home, and .

REGAN: Oh my goodness.

REGAN: . this is a guy who bought into every negative aspect and now he's a member of Congress, and his voting record is abominable. He said Israel shouldn't be financed to have the iron dome. That protects Israeli citizens from rocket attacks, from Gaza. He voted against that. He's one of only eight senators who's voted against Israel .

REGAN: More people speaking out? Good for you, but why are more people saying, my goodness, is this really where you want to take the party, because it's going to disintegrate.

DERSHOWITZ: It's not going to disintegrate. It's going to do what's going all over the world. The left is moving far, far, far, far more to the left. It's going to turn the Democratic Party into the British Labour Party. The British Labour Party is headed by a guy named Corbin, and they can't win an election to dogcatcher. And now the Democrats are going to have their, essentially, Corbin -- he's not as bad as Corbin, but he's pretty darn bad as the head of the Democratic Party, and you're going to a get a lot of centrists saying, I'm no longer Democrat, I'm not going to register as Democrat, I'm not going to .

REGAN: Listen, I meet them all the time here on the show, I mean I've meet quite a few that liked what they heard from say Joe Biden,, like what they heard -- even from Bernie Sanders to a certain extent and they said, look, I can't be part of this party anymore. As I said, who would you, by the way, put in Ellison's place?

DERSHOWITZ: Well, Jennifer Granholm, with the former governor of Michigan, who comes from that part of the country, who has tremendous appeal to middle class people. If Joe Biden would take it, he would be fantastic .

REGAN: He may be running for president, Alan.

DERSHOWITZ: But you gave me a list of a 1000 people, I'd put Ellison a 1001.

REGAN: Yeah.

DERSHOWITZ: He was the worst possible person at this point in the history of the Democratic Party to pick. And I hope the Democratic leaders will come to their senses and say, all right, we put him out there, that was a sap we sent to the Sanders, knees tease, to the hard left of the party, now let's begin to think about how to win. And you don't win with Ellison.

REGAN: Hopefully, they're watching you right now, thank you so much.

DERSHOWITZ: Thank you.

REGAN: Alan, good to have you here.

All right, we're going to talk more about this very issue, Madonna's wing and on the Trump victory blaming women for Hillary Clinton's defeat saying, "women hate women and that's why Clinton didn't win." Well, you know what, that's just wrong. She thinks because you're female you've got to vote for the female? The Democrats keep missing this one, because I'm telling you, the days of identity politics, they are over. We've got more on it next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: OK, we've got some breaking news for you right now. Donald Trump just moments ago came out there to the lobby of Trump Tower with some news. Some news that the SoftBank group founder and CEO is going to be making a big investment, roughly affiliate $50 billion in the United States, the goal to create 50,000 jobs, Japanese company, he then sent a couple of tweets. He said Masa, which is SoftBank, of Japan has agreed to invest $50 billion in the U.S., towards businesses 50,000 new job. And then he tweeted this said, the company would never do this had we, meaning Trump, not won the election.

With the very latest, I want to go to Blake Burman at Trump Tower. A little bit of surprise, there from Donald Trump there this afternoon. I understand he just spoke with some of you there in the lobby. Tell us about it.

BURMAN: Yeah, just spoke with Masayoshi Son the CEO of SoftBank. And put it to him, Trish, point-blank, I said if Donald Trump were not the next president of the United States. Would you not have made this pledge, the $50 billion and 50,000 jobs? And he looked to me and he said that's right. That is indeed the case. I asked him how would these 50,000 jobs come about are you just going to hire a bunch of folks or how is that come about? And he says, Son did that, they will invest in start-ups and that will be the goal to create jobs from there on out. He cited deregulation as a reason for this investment, and he also said that business people are energized. That's one of the reasons why he has come to this.

He also told me the he approached the President-Elect Mr. Trump with this pledge, I guess if that's the way you want to put it this commitment. And should also note, Trish, this is now the second time that Mr. Trump has come to the lobby today to speak with reporters. On the second occasion now, pretty big announcement.

REGAN: Pretty big and, you know, but -- them related to the economy, related to business, you know, first obviously in the case of Boeing basically saying, look, you know, $4 billion is too much .

BURMAN: Right.

REGAN: . for that plane. And now here saying he's got a company a Japanese company that's going to put some money into the U.S. and create jobs. So, look, it's good to hear people are looking for some kind of reason to be optimistic about the economy right now, Blake?

BURMAN: Yeah, absolutely that -- you know, that's a great connection to put those two together with Boeing and now with this announcement from SoftBank. It is the first time we've heard from the president-elect here in New York City speaking to the media. So clearly, he thinks these are two big issues that he wants to get his voice out off.

REGAN: Business top of the agenda, the economy matters, jobs, jobs, jobs.

BURMAN: Right.

REGAN: Thank you so much Blake. We'll keep checking in with you.

Turning right now to Democrats that are still up in arms over Donald Trump's election, and Hollywood being forced to come to terms with the idea that, you know what, no one really cares what they think.

Madonna tells one magazine that she feels like someone died. It's like a nightmare, she says, and she just can't believe Donald Trump is president. But instead of blaming a terrible campaign in a flat candidate, guess what? She's blaming women. This is Madonna. She says, "Women hate women, that's what I think this is. Women's nature is not to support other women. It's really sad. Men protect each other, and women protect their men and children." Really? She lost because women hate women? Are one on the Democrats just going to get overall this identity politics, because I'll tell you what the reality is, women are not bounds by just that. They want whoever, male or female, is best for their future and yes their children and their husband's future. It's not all about what gender you are. And the sooner the Democrats can realize that, the better off they'll be.

Anyway, joining me right now on the issue, we have Republican strategist, Mercedes Schlapp, and Democratic strategist, Brian king. Good to see you guys.

BRIAN KING, DEMOCRAT STRATEGIST: Hey.

REGAN: You know, Mercedes, you are woman, you're Hispanic and you voted for Donald Trump. What is it that Madonna doesn't get about all your identities there?

MERCEDES SCHLAPP, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: And so did my mother and my aunt and my sister and my sister-in-law, they all voted for Donald Trump. Well here's the thing, I think for Madonna she's expressing her inner Secretary Madeleine Albright comment of those women that don't vote for Hillary Clinton, how the special place in hell. We need to remember that women are not monolithic. We vote and understand that there are issues that are important to us. And the Democrats have been stuck in the 1970s-1980s politics of well it's about reproductive rights.

Well its not just about reproductive rights, it's about the economy, it's about health care, it's about education for our families. And I think that when you compare the two candidates in this election, Donald Trump came out with a very strong economic message for families for women that would boost the economy. And we're obviously starting to see this beginning to roll out even before he has been sworn into office.

REGAN: Yeah, he made two economic announcements today. One criticizing some of the waste he sees at Boeings. And the other that Japan is going to make this big investment via SoftBank creating 50,000 new jobs. And are our Blake Burman spoke to the CEO of SoftBank who said, look, this is very much tied to Donald Trump being there and I call them up they want to do this because he's there and I see it as a more pro-business, less regulatory heavy environment right now. Brian.

KING: Yes.

REGAN: What do you think about your party, right now? We just had Alan Dershowitz on saying, you know, he's saying is well this stuff has end to. I mean, they're going to put Keith Ellison as head of the DNC.

KING: Well as pretty this way, and I think Trish we're probably all in agreement that what's amazing, you know, is actually Democrats that understood back in 1992 that it's the economy, stupid. And we knew that and actually we kept winning elections when we said that. And that really is what this is about. And I think, you know, we just saw that a news update. It's the economy stupid that's what we need to keep talking about that's what the .

REGAN: All right, but that's not what they're talking about, Mercedes, right now ...

KING: Right.

REGAN: . it still identity politics, you know, as usual .

KING: And here's what I think is this.

REGAN: . and that Keith Ellison thing.

KING: Here's what I think is so amusing which is, we haven't talked about Madonna since what, 1982. And so, here she comes like what on earth we're talking about Madonna.

REGAN: Maybe she's just trying to make herself relevant.

KING: Right.

REGAN: Maybe that is what this is about. You know, she wants to sell a few albums. You go ahead Mercedes.

KING: But quite frankly we should be talking more Springsteen if you want to talk about the economy.

REGAN: Mercedes.

SCHLAPP: But this is part of the problem I think with Hollywood and itself and I would say a number of the Democrats is the fact that, that being disconnected from the struggle of the American worker.

And so, I think when you bring back a Nancy Pelosi, for example, as leading your party in the House where she's a San Francisco liberal, you know, not necessarily understanding what's happening in the middle of the heart of America where so many companies have left communities leaving individuals and families devastated. I think that's where the disconnect has happened with the Democratic Party.

And what we've seen as a party move further to the left without necessarily providing the economic solutions, and I think .

REGAN: Yeah.

SCHLAPP: . that's why Donald Trump has come in and said, look, I am not the politician, I'm a businessman, I want to negotiate these deals, I want to work with the parties to push forward a strong economic agenda.

REGAN: It's really interesting to see and it's just going to get even more interesting from here, Mercedes and Brian, thank you so much.

KING: Thank you Trish.

SCHLAPP: Thank you Trish.

REGAN: All right, everyone, we got some web giants out there like Youtube, Facebook, Twitter and Microsoft all bonding together right now today to remove extremist contents and terrorist propaganda from their sites. OK. Sounds good. But where they're then? Right? I mean why didn't they do this a whole long time ago? Could it be because Donald Trump is now in office, about to be in office that these companies are suddenly trying to clean up their acts? We're on the story next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: All right. Let's check out this market which is now in positive territory, again, market moving higher here. but fairly up 19 points, there on the Dow. S&P also in the green as well. The NASDAQ Composite Index to get energy companies, however, struggling a bit more as the price of oil really had lower today after a four day long rally, but still above that key $50 level. You see oil closing out the day just a moment ago.

All right, let's turn right now to the Supreme Court with deciding with Samsung and its high-profile patent dispute with Apple over the design of the iPhone. The justices today throwing out nearly $400 million judgment against Samsung. The court said Samsung can't be forced to pay all the profits because the copied parts are only a tiny fraction of the devices.

We are going to be right back. And we're going to have a look at this social media websites like Google, Microsoft that seemed to be willing to finally step up to fight terror, what took so long?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: Our news today that Facebook, Microsoft, Twitter and Youtube are all coming together to try to stop the spread of online terror. They plan on using a shared database that will catch potential terrorist activity and remove it from their websites. Hopefully also report it to the FBI.

Facebook released a statement today reading, "We hope this collaboration will lead to greater efficiency as we continue to enforce our policies to help curb the pressing global issue of terrorist content online." OK. Good! Right? I guess the question here though is what the heck took them so long?

Joining me right now we have Fox News Strategist Analyst, Colonel Ralph Peters, and former Treasury Attach, for Saudi Arabia, Morgan Ortagus.

I know you guys have bolt pen all over this. But none of us here on this panel has ever understood why the social media companies have not been more proactive. Is this a sign of potentially more good things to come, Colonel Peters?

LT. COL. RALPH PETERS, (RET.) FOXS NEWS STRATEGIC ANALYST: Well, let us hope. But I think it's easy explained why the tech companies have done nothing, greed, raw greed at the expense of human lives. They have positioned themselves, marketed themselves as great benefactors of humanity. But the big tech companies, you know, Facebook, Google, Microsoft, or Youtube, they have been the number one enabler of ISIS and other terrorist groups. And all ,by the way, let's not forget fake news which result which has resulted in a gunman walking into a pizzeria in Washington, D.C.

REGAN: Yeah.

PETERS: So, it's a long way -- they have a long way to go to make good. They've got a lot of blood on their hands.

REGAN: You know, one of the things I never kind of understood, Morgan, you know, not my fault, not my problem. You know, we can't entirely control and we don't want to have to limit the communication between these people to which I'd just say, you know, don't you have some kind of national duty? You are American companies, you've gotten your start in this country and all the benefits that come with that. Don't you have an obligation to help protect the citizens of the United States of America?

MORGAN ORTAGUS, FMR. STATE DEPARTMENT PRESS OFFICER: Absolutely, Trish, and I'm glad that they're finally speaking up and doing something about it. This has been a problem .

PETERS: Yeah.

ORTAGUS: . mainly because ISIS is, you know, how millennials do terror so to speak. They know, because these are millennials actually running the media machines within ISIS. These are very sophisticated things that the people can find online. They know how to distribute, they know how to make videos, they know how to distribute the videos, they know how to package it for a young audience and to get the most maximum media attention.

So, when you look at these social media companies, if there is any like child pornography, for example, that goes onto their website, that stuff gets taken down right away. So, I've been arguing for the past year, if you're able to find the resources and algorithms and manpower to remove content which is horrible such as child pornography. You should also be able to do that with terrorism-related activities.

REGAN: Yeah. It looks it's a no-brainer.

ORTAGUS: Totally.

REGAN: Colonel Peters, you know, you think back historically to how we have been as a country. And you think back, you know, to previous wars, you know, look, the allies cracked enigma and had a central role in really decoding what the enemy was doing. Don't we need social media companies to step up all over the world, frankly, and really work to decode the enemy which, in this case, is extremism, Islamic extremism online?

PETERS: Well, we certainly do, but let's remember, you referenced enigma in World War II. American industry had conscience. They were CEO'S that went to work for a dollar a year, the dollar a year made. We rallied behind our troops. But these big tech companies do not feel that they're really American citizens or citizens of the world, they have no sense of responsibility, and again, they've got enormous amount of blood in their hands and they won't face up to it. And we'll see .

REGAN: Or maybe they're going to have to. Because, you know, Donald Trump is there right now, and he's made it very clear Morgan, that he's not going to stand for this. It's one of the reasons, by the way, a lot of this tech companies have been suffering ever since he was announced.

ORTAGUS: That's a good point Trish. It's also reputational risk, you know, whenever you're in Facebook or Twitter, whomever and whenever ISIS is using your medium in order to kill people in Syria to cause genocide, to cause mass civil war, that's a mass of reputational risk from a business perspective.

REGAN: Yeah. They need to worry about that a little bit more, because .

ORTAGUS: Absolutely.

REGAN: . a lot of them are communicating right now. And I hope they .

ORTAGUS: They are.

REGAN: . start to care more about their reputational work, and I hope that our president .

ORTAGUS: Yeah.

REGAN: . forces them to start to care a little bit more about it. Morgan and Colonel Peters, thank you so much.

ORTAGUS: OK

REGAN: We're taking a quick break. I'll see you right back here in two.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Ladies and gentlemen, this is Masa of SoftBank from Japan and he's just agreed to invest $50 billion in the United States and 50,000 jobs. And he's one of the great men of industry. So I just want to thank you.

MASAYOSHI SON, SOFTBANK, CEO: Thank you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

REGAN: All right, that news just breaking just a short time ago. You saw Donald Trump there in the lobby of Trump Tower with the CEO of SoftBank, said SoftBank is going to be putting $50 billion creating 50,000 jobs into the U.S. economy. Here with more is the author of "The Coming Collapse of China" Gordon Chang, a big critic of China over the years. Gordon, good to see you.

What is this signal to China right now the fact that Japan is going to be putting 50 billion for give me in.

GORDON CHANG, "NUCLEAR SHOWDOWN" AUTHOR: This is what they really worry about Donald Trump. They worry, of course, about the phone call with Tsai Ing-wen, the Taiwan president. But really this is it, because, first of all, you have investments that would have gone into China but now they're coming to the United States. You know, if Trump is successful in reducing taxes and reducing regulation, he's going create that 4 percent growth. That's going to create pressure on the Renminbi, the Chinese currency. That's a real problem for China right now.

REGAN: So the China would have liked to see in Softbank put 50 billion into their economy.

CHANG: Absolutely.

REGAN: OK.

CHANG: And because SoftBank does have relations with China, this is important for them. So, you have a continuing stream of investments. So got to go somewhere, you know, and they're starting to divert away from China for various reasons, some are going to India, some are going to Bangladesh and Vietnam. But we're now starting to see the stream of money coming to the U.S. because of the optimism. You know, the Dow, 11 straight .

REGAN: I know.

CHANG: .records.

REGAN: And it's up again right now, up 22 points as you can see.

CHANG: So this is something that's got to worry China because they've got very fragile economy right now and, you know, they're dependent on us.

REGAN: In other words what you're telling me is, you know, the pie is only so -- to a certain extent only so big and another if we're going to continue to get more of it, it's going to come or they may see this as its coming at their expense.

CHANG: Certainly, you know, we're not in one of those robust global environments. You know, global GDP their share will increase 1 percent, maybe 1.5 percent. You know, trade is going to be very, very low if there's an increase and at very well when be heading into a de-linking of economies.

So, right now, you know, China for instance last year their economy de- linked from the global economy. They had 8.0 percent less trade. This year it's going to be down about 7.5 percent. So, tie it right now is in fragile.

REGAN: But what does it all mean? I mean, are they going to have to, you know, knock it off with some of the tariffs that are on our good that are coming in to their economy? How does this change? Are they going to have to stop, you know, depreciating their currency?

CHANG: You would think so, but Xi Jinping the Chinese ruler believes in China first. He has been closing off the Chinese market to foreign companies. This has been going on now for about three years.

REGAN: And this is one reason why you say that phone call was kind of a good thing because it sort of the destabilized of the situation in just a little tiny way enough to, you know, throw them off their game?

CHANG: Well, you know, what's happening here is that, you know, Trump has signaled that he has going to change foreign policy 100 percent.

REGAN: Isn't it amazing, amazing. Gordon Chang, thank you so much. We're going to be right back.

CHANG: Thanks Trish.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

REGAN: All right, it's only 3:00 and we've already heard from Donald Trump twice there in Trump Tower, just most recently, moments ago saying that he has secured a pledge from SoftBank, the Japanese company, to put $50 billion into the U.S. economy creating 50,000 jobs.

President Obama is going to be arriving in Florida today. He's expected to thank some of the country's special operations forces and deliver his last national security speech while in office. It's all going to happen in just about 30 minutes from now. So stay tuned for that. Liz will have it.

END

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5MBG-0TF1-DXH2-6311-00000-00Trump Blasts Boeing Deal; Trump's First 100 Days; Biden To Run In 2020; Pentagon Hides $125B Waste; Dershowitz Blasts Dem Pick to Lead DNC; Madonna: Women Betrayed Us; SoftBank To Invest In U.S.; Hollywood Hypocrisy; Pres Obama To Speak At 3:362016-12-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:27ZLexisNexisINTELLIGENCE REPORT2:00 PM ESTEdwin Meese, Tom Fitton, Tim Carney, Tim Phillips, Alan Dershowitz, Brian Keene, Morgan Ortagus, Gordon ChangNEWSInternational120601cb.232Trump Blasts BoeingDeal; Trump's First 100 Days; Biden To Run In 2020; Pentagon Hides $125B Waste; Dershowitz Blasts Dem Pick to Lead DNC; Madonna: Women Betrayed Us; SoftBank To Invest In U.S.; Hollywood Hypocrisy; Pres Obama To Speak At 3:36Trish Regan, Blake Burman, Mercedes Schlapp, Ralph Peters

NEIL CAVUTO, FBN HOST: But a quick footnote on the Russell, it has had double the gains of the Dow close to 19 percent year to date. Trish Regan, to you!

TRISH REGAN, FBN HOST: All right. Thanks so much, Neil.

President-Elect Donald Trump taking on government waste today, blasting Boeingfor wasting taxpayer dollars on a new presidential plane, Air Force One.

I am Trish Regan. Welcome everyone to "The Intelligence Report".
