urn:contentItem:5WFD-9FB1-DY0W-42PK-00000-00Trump Bringing America First to Davos; Homeland Security Head Discusses the Wall; Steven Mnuchin Says Low Dollar Is Good For Economy;2018-01-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:38:27ZLexisNexisTrump Bringing America First to Davos; Homeland Security Head Discusses the Wall; Steven Mnuchin Says Low Dollar Is Good For Economy;LanhamFULL TEXT

ANNOUNCER: Here is Maria Bartiromo with a special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Good Wednesday morning, everybody, thanks so much for joining us, I am Maria Bartiromo, editors Wednesday, January 24. Your top stories right now, 6:00 a.m. on the east coast, bringing America First to the world stage, President Trump and his administration in Davos, the administration cabinet landing here, the president arriving on Thursday. To tout the United States economy and lure new big-name investors. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin already on the ground at the World Economic Forum.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

STEVEN MNUCHIN, TREASURY SECRETARY: We couldn't be happier to be here. It's all about economic growth, opportunities to invest, free and fair trade and we are looking forward to it. I think is going to have lots of good interaction.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Secretary Mnuchin later said that a weaker dollar is good for the US economy and trade, what sent to dollars sliding this morning. Plus, trickle-down tax reform, Disney detailing plans to pass on the savings from the new law by giving a $1000 cash bonus to 125,000 employees. Big news coming after similar announcements from JPMorgan Chase yesterday in Verizon as well.

The very latest wins for American workers coming up this morning. Earnings the story in business again this morning. General Electric, Ford, Comcast all of the names set to report their fourth-quarter numbers today. GE expecting earnings of $0.29 a share, we will bring you those numbers as soon as they hit the tape throughout the morning.

Markets this morning look like this. The Nasdaq surged 52 points yesterday after Netflix shares jumped 10 percent. S&P 500 closing at an all-time high. These markets continue to be on fire. Dow industrials down just a fraction yesterday. But the Nasdaq with a three-quarter of a percent move in unchartered territory yet again.

This morning here is the story. Futures indicating the markets will open like this and we are looking at gains once again. The momentum continues. Dow industrials up another 55 points right now. Nasdaq up 10 points this morning.

In Europe the major indices look like this. Take a look at the trading this morning with the major indices lower. FTSE 100 down 1/4 of a percent. The other managers flat on the session.

In Asia overnight, markets close mostly higher. The best performer there as you can see in China. Shanghai composite up a third of a percent. Japan, Nikkei average down three-quarter of 1 percent.

King James ground early, Lebron celebrating his new spot in the 30,000 club before actually making history. The hilarious reaction to the premature celebration coming up this morning. Also coming up this morning joining us, Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen is with us. Energy Secretary Rick Perry is with us. The chairman of UBS, largest wealth manager in the world, Axel Weber will join me. The CEO of Bank of America, Brian Moynihan is here.

Plus, Dow DuPont chairman and CEO, Andrew Liverus will be with us. We will get a sense of business today coming up in a jampacked program. And we kick it off right now with this top story bringing America First to Davos.

Trump headed here to the World Economic Forum tonight. The president firing back at Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer last night for offering and then rescinding a deal to support border wall funding in exchange for legal protections for illegal immigrants brought to the United States as children.

The president tweeted this last night, crying Chuck Schumer fully understands especially after is his humiliating defeat that if there is no wall there is no DACA. We must have safety and security together with a strong military for our great people.

Joining me now in Davos is the Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen NielSEN. Great to see you. Thank you for joining us. Let's talk about immigration. Explain the wall. Tell us why the wall is important for security, not just a talking point, but actually security.

KIRSTJEN NIELSEN, HOMELAND SECURITY SECRETARY: I appreciate that. The wall itself is a system. So, when we talk about the world I really mean a system. So, it is infrastructure, which is some sort of physical structure, but also the personnel and technology that go with it. So, we have to need all three together to get the security.

And I think what we see in the United States with examples in Yuma, Arizona and San Diego in California, when we put up a wall system, we have actually decreased illegal border crossings by 95 percent. So, we have evidence it works. There are certain places on the border will be need this. We work very closely with state and local when we can, we try to find a dual use, so we are looking at levees for example, so we have the dual use of security and helping the community not flood.

BARTIROMO: What is your response to what Senator Schumer said? Now he is withdrawing the immigration offer. I know that I've heard Schumer and others talk about the need for security, border security in the past and last night he changed his tune.

NIELSEN: I can't see what he changed his tune, it's a bit confusing to me as well. He's voted for the security fence act in the past as have many Democrats. It's a bipartisan issue. It is a clear need in our country, we have agreed it is one of the four pillars for discussion. So hopefully we come back around and move forward in our discussions.

BARTIROMO: What is a state of security today? You've got a lot on your plate from actual border situations to cyber, so can you give us a status check in terms of American homeland security?

NIELSEN: Absolutely. So, I think what we are seeing is terrorists, nation states whether across the board are changing their tune. So, what we need to do is we need to continue to evolve and make sure that we can meet the incoming changing threats.

And that is why I'm here today. So, we need to do that in partnership, there is not one entity that has all the resources and capabilities to address any of these threats alone. So, we have to look at it from an international domestic, from a public-private and certainly within the United States government, a whole of government approach to address these threats.

BARTIROMO: What are the threats? Is it transnational gangs, is it drug lords, who is coming across the border?

NIELSEN: we do have a large TCO problem, yes. So transnational criminal organizations smuggle all things, the smuggle people, drugs, they can smuggle weapons. We work very closely with our partners to the south and within the international community to try to combat that, but we need to do more within the United States, not only stopping them at the border but frankly I need the ability to be able to remove them once I do stop them at the border, and that is part of our discussions right now with Congress.

BARTIROMO: How much an issue is homegrown terrorism at this point? We have seen that obviously people getting inspired by ISIS. Where we are not?

NIELSEN: Terrorist used of the Internet is the first thing that comes to mind when we talk about that, we do see them inspiring, we do see them recruiting, we see them financing over the Internet, that is something that we are working with companies here today in Davos to further that discussion. It is a problem, so we need to understand what causes one to become radicalized. But if there is a way to take them off that path and give them perhaps a more constructive way forward. Sort of different parts of the process that we are working on.

BARTIROMO: I thought it was really fascinating that even with the government shutdown, the US was able to kill 150 ISIS fighters in Syria due to the airstrikes there. Extraordinary.

NIELSEN: Yes, and we must continue to remove their safe haven. That is a very important step. Secretary Mattis if he were here he would tell you and thank the troops for what they have done and all of our military, but what we as homeland security no need to do is make sure that they don't, they fall apart if you will, if they don't have a safe haven to not come to the United States. So, we are working with international partners to increase that screening Internet sure the terrorists not coming to the United States.

We released a report last week, we meet seven terrorists a day trying to come to our country legally, they are on the terrorist watch list. It is an ongoing problem. Need to make sure we have the tools to defend our country.

BARTIROMO: What do you need to do that effectively? We are having this debate over funding for the border wall, but also funding in general for the for the military as the Democrats want what they want in terms of DACA. Tell us the needs in terms of homeland security.

NIELSEN: Some of this as you say is funding. I think we have been very clear. We have a very clear proposal with respect to the wall system, were that would go and how that would work. But also need the ability to promptly remove those that I stop at the border. This is where I am confused because this is border security. If I stop 20 people at the border but I have to let them into the country, that is not border security. So, we need to work with Congress to close the loopholes that have evolved over time through the courts, so that if someone comes and they don't have any legal right, they don't have any other claim, for example such as asylum, I need the ability to be all the remove them at that point at the border. Then we don't have an interior problem.

BARTIROMO: In other words, you can just send them right back.

NIELSEN: No, ma'am.

BARTIROMO: Why?

NIELSEN: A lot of court cases to be honest, it is just the way that the courts have evolved you find a very sympathetic case, and unfortunately the law is made around that case, the exception becomes the rule. And suddenly the rule is the exception meaning I can't stop anyone. So, we've given these proposals to Congress and I'm very hopeful that we can make the case that is border security, it is not interior security, it is not integration enforcement, it is border security right there at the border.

BARTIROMO: What you want to see from corporate America? I mean companies in terms of verifying who was working for that company, are there a lot of stories of companies that hiding illegals?

NIELSEN: I don't know about a lot of stories, but we do unfortunately see bad actors. We do seek companies who consistently and persistently violate our laws. We will have to work on that. As you have seen with 7 Eleven recently, that has been a problem in the past, we noticed them. And so, then we had to take enforcement action against the company at the company level.

E-verify as you know right now is a voluntary program, it enables you to assure that who you are hiring has the legal right to work in the United States. We encourage all employers to use it. But if you are purposely evading our laws we will prosecute. We do need to enforce our laws.

BARTIROMO: Even sanctuary cities? I find it extraordinary that California can just get away with being a sanctuary city. In just blowing off the federal law.

NIELSEN: Yes, you know what I find really disturbing about that is I can't find anyone who would tell me they don't want the criminals out. So, this is where I get very confused, what at the heart of this discussion of sanctuary cities is, I can get a criminal, my folks can go get a criminal in jail which is a safe area, it is a controlled area. They can pick that person up. They can detain them for federal purposes on the way out to be deported.

If a so-called sanctuary city left that person out into the community, my officials are then forced to go into the community which puts everyone at risk, not just my officers but frankly the immigrant community as well. So, I get very confusing people talk about sanctuary city. It is a sanctuary for criminals. It is not a sanctuary for immigrants. So really need to work with cities to make sure that we can understand the safest way to do this is to remove the criminals in a controlled environment.

BARTIROMO: Is there accountability? Should a city not remove those criminals?

NIELSEN: In my opinion, they should work with ICE and let ICE come pick them out. By the way we are not asking them to do anything special, just before you are going to release someone, 48 hours before you do let us know. We will come get them. If we can't get something we can't get them. But we would like to try, we would like the ability to be able to take them in a controlled way so that we can then put them into proceeding.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you that your testimony last week before the senate judiciary committee when New Jersey Democrat Booker really exploded on you over language that the president may or may not have used in the oval office on immigration. Here's the exchange.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. CORY BOOKER, (D) NEW JERSEY: The commander-in-chief in an oval office meeting referring to people from African countries and Haitians with the most wild and vulgar language. I had tears of rage when I heard about this experience in that meeting, you don't remember. You can't remember the words of your commander-in-chief. I find that unacceptable. Your silence and amnesia are complicity.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: What did you make of Senator Booker's behavior toward you?

NIELSEN: To be honest it was a distraction, and it was very frustrating to me on behalf of the men and women of the Department of Homeland Security, because I was there to talk about real threats and their needs to do their job. That the American people has asked him to do.

It became 11 minutes of a lecture about a meeting he was not in about one word and whether or not I heard it. I said under testimony was that possible? Sure. I just did not hear the word. There is no story there. He didn't ask me what I think, he didn't ask me what I think about the countries, he didn't ask me what I think about immigration policy. He had no interest about what the Secretary of Homeland security thinks. He just wants to lecture me for 11 minutes. So, it was unfortunate, it was an unfortunate waste of all of our time, one recruiter been focused on the needs and threats.

BARTIROMO: It felt to me like harassment. Did you feel harassed?

NIELSEN: I felt it was just inappropriate. That is a workplace environment, he didn't seem constructive to me, it didn't seem productive. It wasn't a conversation. There wasn't any opportunity for me to explain how I feel which I would think is what he would be interested as the Secretary of Homeland Security. And again, he wasn't even in the meeting, so it was a bit confusing as to why he felt that it was appropriate to tell me what I heard and didn't hear, when he wasn't even there.

BARTIROMO: It seems obviously like he wanted a platform, so that he could do a show, maybe he was to run for president. How is the new job going? You handled that very well. Tell us your observations from this that you have.

NIELSEN: I'm so proud of the men and women of DHS. They put their lives on the line everyday. We have a huge portfolio, we have many threats. But it is a great job. It is the order of a lifetime to be able to support them and protect the American people.

BARTIROMO: What should we expect from the president tomorrow?

NIELSEN: I think what his message is going to be is America First is not America alone. We need a partner. Not one of us has the ability to do this alone. We need to partner with the private sector, we need to partner with our allies. We see that in discussions about North Korea, Syria, Iran. We have to build coalitions to attack these threats together. That is what you will hear a lot about.

BARTIROMO: Is there is threat from North Korea currently on the ground, Homeland Security that we should be aware of?

NIELSEN: What we worry about of course is with the missile testing and ongoing nuke program, with that means for us. Should they be able to develop the capability to reach the United States? I want to make sure we are prepared. What does that mean for the homeland? So that is every thing from alert and warning systems. We see lately that we need some work there to connect, but it also means being prepared for the consequences if any should occur.

BARTIROMO: Secretary Nielsen, it's good to have you on the program.

NIELSEN: My pleasure.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us.

We will take a break. When we come back the weak dollar is good apparently. That is the word from Treasury Secretary Mnuchin. We break down more of his comments and the impact on markets this morning. Dollar is lower.

And all eyes on General Electric after a huge fall, the company reports quarterly earnings within the hour after a dismal year. We will bring you the numbers as soon as they hit the tape. Stay with us right here live from Davos.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Gunfire causing panic at another school to report. Cheryl Casone with the details.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN HOST: Good morning to you. Maria. A 15-year-old student opened fire at Marshall County High School killing two fellow students and injuring 18 others. Police say the suspect is in custody and will be charged with two counts of murder, and several counts of attempted murder. Officials haven't decided if he'll be tried as an adult. According to "The New York Times," and this is the 11th school shooting since January 1st and roughly the 50th of the academic year.

The dollar hitting fresh lows this morning after Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that he welcomes a weakening dollar because it is good for trade. The euro is now hitting a three year high on those comments. While attending the World Economic Forum in Davos where you are, Maria, Secretary Mnuchin also said that America is open for business.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MNUCHIN: We have a great story to tell, lots of important meetings, all about economic growth, opportunities to invest in a free and fair trade. We are looking forward to it.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: This is coming after fair protectionism already push the dollar lower. Trump is set to leave the United States for Davos tonight. The United States Senate voting Tuesday on President Trump's pick for the federal reserve. Jerome Powell was confirmed as the next fed chair in a landslide vote. Powell signaled during confirmation hearings that he agrees with the central bank's current policies, including gradual increases in interest rates. He will replace Janet Yellen who was the first woman to leave the fed, Yellen's for your turn parents officially on February 3.

And we are going to get earnings from two Dow components this morning. Investors in General Electric get ready. They are bracing for possibly more bad news after the company recently announced a surprise charge from its insurance business. Earnings-per-share expect to fall nearly 38 percent from a year ago. Those are the estimates. We should say the stock was a little bit higher a few moments ago. It has actually scaled-back it is up .12 percent.

And then let's look at United Technologies, they reported actually just a few minutes ago, posted better than expected results. Sales rising in all four of the business units there. United Technologies stock is up 22 percent from just a year ago. But obviously all eyes this morning, Maria, on General Electric. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: Already, it also obviously, Steven Mnuchin's comments, we will talk more about that coming up in the program, thank you.

The tax plan giveback continues, Verizon, Disney, JPMorgan and Starbucks all plan financial perks for employees because of the new tax cuts. I will speak with Bank of America chairman and CEO, Brian Moynihan, coming up about the impact.

Plus, crypto currency is a big topic of discussion here in Davos, but is the technology behind it, block chain, the much bigger economic game changer? We are getting some answers this morning, back in a moment, right here live.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: Verizon announced today that all of their employees other than a top management will receive 50 shares of restricted stock. This amounts to about $2500 per employee. Employees will further share in the company's success, Verizon said in a release. We are only one year in and the president is just getting started.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: White House Press Secretary Sarah Sanders detailing Verizon's plan to reward employees as a result of President Trump's tax plan. Not the only company with a big announcement yesterday. Disney announced employee bonuses and JPMorgan Chase raised wages. My next guest was among the first to announce plans to give money back to employees. Bank of America, chairman and CEO, Brian Moynihan is with us now. Brian, great to see you.

BRIAN MOYNIHAN, CHAIRMAN AND CEO, BANK OF AMERICA: Good morning. Wonderful day.

BARTIROMO: Really is. You announced employees getting their $1000 bonus citing the tax bill.

MOYNIHAN: It was a broader package. When the tax bill came out, we believed we had to share success with our teammates. It is one of our core principles. So, if you earned under $150,000, we gave them a $1000 bonus that they got in their paychecks by year end.

But it was on the backs, we moved to $15 an hour last year at this time as a starting wage. It employees will work for a company from 2010 to now, it is in the bracket that we are talking about, has had an average wage increase of 5 percent per year. It is a constant war for talent out there at all levels of our company.

BARTIROMO: So how long does this go on? One of your colleagues in the business said to me, people are looking at this as if it is an overnight success. The truth is going to be a lot longer and sustainable than people think. How do you see it?

MOYNIHAN: We were on a panel yesterday together. If you think about it, the tax reform is a month old. We all had a one-time adjustments we had to make in our year end financial statements, so we had some programs. The question is what we do. We are increasing our investment and we told our investors on our earnings call we consider increasing investments, speeding up the pace stuff that we are doing, more branches in new cities which have about 10 employees.

All of those things. Like companies around the world, it will take a little while for people to catch up to because it is brand-new. And so, they are adjusting business plans and their spending plans, but your hearing across the board, incremental aggressiveness, incremental focus on investing on stuff that has a little longer payback. With an equal balance if are going to give investments extra earnings, stock buybacks, dividends, which is it bad either.

Because that is going to go back in the economy and the investor gets that is going to have to put it to work with some company that needs more capital will take it and put it to work.

BARTIROMO: Yes, let's talk about more capital. Generally, the regulations that you have been faced with for the last 10 years, which are beginning to get brought back. The Trump administration has announced a pretty good rollback in regulations but hasn't even impacted the banks yet. Isn't that right?

MOYNIHAN: Well, if you think about the regulations for banking, we needed to get the situation right, we had a ton of regulations. And the expectation would be they would swing past the point of the middle. And if you think about what we need to do going forward, the people running the agencies and the regulatory process, those people are now in place, Chairman Powell was approved yesterday.

That was important. The second was to new regulations that were inconsistent, adding on, piling on, whatever the right word you might use. Because we had fixed everything frankly. We are kind of done. And even Tarullo we did a good job of bringing the regulation forward, declares it was kind of over. But we had to stop the momentum.

And then the third thing is Mnuchin with Craig Phillips and the team in treasury, working with the industry, people who like the industry and people who don't like the industry, came up with a roadmap to appropriately rebalance the regulation. As one of the largest underwriters of the FDIC fund with my other banks, putting in money, we have the highest interest in the safest and soundest banking industry. Because anytime a bank fails the industry puts up the money ultimately, and we put up about a 14 or 15 percent share of that. So, I have a higher interest than a lot of people to make sure this is safe and sound industry.

BARTIROMO: What I was getting out it seems like there is a long runway. You haven't even felt the impact yet. A big deal for Bank of America and the entire industry.

MOYNIHAN: I think it will take time. And you have to do it right, and has got to be it has got to be carefully done with the right cost benefit analysis. We can't keep changing back and forth. As we fix Volcker, it's got to have stick to the ribs to it. It has to have integrity to it that does the purpose which was intended to stop proprietary trading. Remove some of the difficulty in compliance, the sticks to it, so somebody doesn't have a better idea in two years, because the system requirements and the fixes for this. We spent over $1 billion on a resolution plan. I don't want that to have to be redone. That is really money that just goes to consultants and teammates and other people and systems, but it really doesn't do anything for our customers.

BARTIROMO: You need certainly, I get that, to plan. Characterize the consumer, your business has been going very well. Growth obviously at Bank of America. Can you tell us how the consumer looks in terms of lending, spending right now?

MOYNIHAN: Sure. If you start the broad thing of what happened last year, from 2015 to 2016, all the spending in the consumers which is about two and one quarter trillion dollars, Bank of America grew about three percent. 2016 to 2017 that same spending whether it is checks or debit credit cards, money out of the ATM, groom at six percent.

So twice the rate across 2.6 trillion last year. In January off to start again. Consumers have been spending, it is a little more driven at the implement by experiences as opposed to things. Doing stuff as opposed to buying stuff.

BARTIROMO: Going out to dinner, there spending money there.

MOYNIHAN: A vacation. And as wages continue to rise, as wealth continues to build a market, you going to see that is one of the attributes of that. That's very constructive. On a lending side, we are a prime lender, the credit statistics are very strong. The availability of credit is very strong.

I made it my mission since then to get justice for Sergei Magnitsky which has resulted in the Magnitsky Act which imposes sanctions on the Putin regime and there are now four other countries above and beyond America -- Canada, the U.K., Lithuania and Estonia that have Magnitsky Acts.

I'm working all over the world to get a similar legislation. And Putin is absolutely apoplectic because Putin is one of the richest men in the world. He's got money everywhere. He is afraid that his money will be frozen.

He's personally angry at me for this. I've been threatened with death, kidnapping, arrests, extradition. It's a major, major problem for Vladimir Putin.

BARTIROMO: You walk around with security?

BARTIROMO: Ok. Got you, got you.

BROWDER: Absolutely.

BARTIROMO: I remember years ago when I traveled to Moscow and I also traveled to St. Petersburg to the St. Petersburg International Conference, I was told don't bring your Blackberry. As soon as you enter -- and this was 10 years ago --

BROWDER: Yes.

BARTIROMO: As soon as you enter Russian airspace, the Russians will hack you and they will have access to your rolodex and your calendar and et cetera.

BROWDER: They've been doing it for 50 years.

BARTIROMO: There is nothing new about Donald Trump.

Russia was interfering everywhere. And it's a nonpartisan thing. If they could've interfered with -- if they could have talked to the Clinton campaign, they would have talked to the Clinton campaign.

BARTIROMO: Somebody tried to run against him. And the election was what - - what happened. He said no, you can't run.

BARTIROMO: So what is the world to do? I mean what do you want to tell these world leaders here in Davos about Russia and partnering with Russia.

BROWDER: What I tell them is that Putin is out to create chaos and destroy democracy and freedoms in the world. And we have to contain him and surround him. He is a man who wishes us nothing but ill.

BARTIROMO: All right. We will leave it there. Bill -- great to see you. Thanks so much for weighing in.

You have had a great, you know, since the 2008 crisis, we've had a -- we've finally got into a sustained recovery and now what you see happening that with our business is that as we've seen here in Davos if you go back three or four years, we were talking about the internet of things and now the fourth industrial revolution, and there's no doubt that that's occurring, and no one is talking about it. So here we're having conversations about how do we redefine the architecture inside a vehicle. Those are the conversations we're having now. So technology is permeating every aspect of life and industry, and as that happens as billions of things become connected. Obviously, that's good for us.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Let's talk about that because we were talking with Carlo Stone yesterday and he was saying, everything in a car today is technology related. So what areas of business are the most important in terms of powering your business? What sectors?

ROBBINS: Well, if you look at -- it's happening across every industry today. Primarily, we have seen early adoption in manufacturing of this industrial internet. We've seen retail move.

BARTIROMO: Sorry about that.

ROBBINS: That's great.

BARTIROMO: This must mean someone important is arriving.

ROBBINS: I know.

BARTIROMO: Because a helicopter is here making lots of noise but hopefully they just passed. So you said manufacturing --

ROBBINS: Well, I just want you to know when I arrived in Davos, I wouldn't interrupt you like that visitor, you know, we've seen manufacturing. We've seen healthcare. We see connected cars. We made announcements of CES with Hyundai. I meet with a couple of car manufacturers here this week about what we can do together and then across our broader business just the connectivity of all these devices, the management of the data, the cybersecurity issues that are associated with it. They all provide great opportunities for us in the future.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Because everything is connected today, so tell us how the Cisco products connect?

ROBBINS: Well, so I think they're circling to come back to see if they -- make sure you heard them the first time. So when you -- when you look at the connectivity of all of the platforms, the --

BARTIROMO: Stop. Just give it a minute first. It's going back at out, yes.

ROBBINS: It's (INAUDIBLE) they're going to land right here.

BARTIROMO: They're right above us.

ROBBINS: They're going to land.

BARTIROMO: This helicopter.

ROBBINS: The matter of the issue is as we connect vehicles, as we connect vending machines, manufacturing facilities whatever they are, Cisco is the largest machine, the machine connectivity platform. Then after that, you have to actually take the data that's created and help our customers move that data to the place that they need it and whether it's in a public crowd, whether it's in a private cloud, or whether they want to assess and manage that data at the edge of the network, the network is going to play a great role, and then we fundamentally have to drive security in the network because there is no perimeter to defend it anymore.

BARTIROMO: Wonderful. Chuck, I'm so sorry.

ROBBINS: What did you say?

BARTIROMO: This is -- this is incredible. We're having a conversation --

ROBBINS: We had a funny experienced last year too, you know.

BARTIROMO: But with the helicopters?

ROBBINS: No. We had one with a camera last year, so --

BARTIROMO: Oh, that's right. Let me ask you real quick in terms of geography and where you see the best growth right now. Europe is growing. The U.S. is obviously a chunk of a four percent growth, is there a corner of the world that is doing better than others with regard to this kind of activity?

ROBBINS: Well, what I would say is that we see probably more consistent growth around the world than we've seen in a very long time as evidence by the discussions going on here. When we look at the adoption of the technology, we see emerging countries adopting the technology to try to solve problems in a massive scale whether it's in India, whether it's in China. And then we see obviously developed countries leveraging these technologies to look at how we make cities smarter that had optimized traffic and optimized citizen services, so it's really happening everywhere, it's amazing. So --

BARTIROMO: Yes. Incredible performance. So how do you keep this going?

ROBBINS: Well, I think that as long as this industrial revolution continues then we should be at the heart of all of that because as our customers connect more and more devices, the network is absolutely the foundation, so --

BARTIROMO: Chuck, it's good to have you on the show. Thank you so much. This is great, this is incredible. This is actually funny.

ROBBINS: They're circling.

BARTIROMO: They're circling. Chuck Robbins, Cisco CEO, we will be right back. Thank you so much.

LEIF SHIRAS, TENNIS CHANNEL COMMENTATOR: Welcome back to another Tennis Channel Court Report, a special presentation For Business. I'm Leif Shairs. Well, the 2018 Austrian Open completed quarterfinal action on day 10 in Melbourne and there was American interest in both the man and woman draws. Kyung Chang ended the dream run of Tennessee native Tenny Sandgren to reach the final four and become the first South Korean to reach the semifinals at a major.

Elsewhere, Angelique Kerber made short work of Maidson Keys in their quarterfinal. The American never found her game as the German powered away to an impressive one and two victory. Don't forget, Tennis Channel's live coverage of the Australian Open continues Wednesday at 6:00 p.m. Eastern. I'm Leif Sharis.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Here again Maria Bartiromo with the special edition of MORNINGS WITH MARIA live from Davos, Switzerland at the World Economic Forum.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, January 24th. Your top stories right now 8:34 on the East Coast. The White House descends on Davos. President Trump set to leave Washington for the World Economic Forum tonight. The trip comes as the White House makes good on the Commander-in-Chief's promise to put America first, this follows the overwhelming success of the President's tax plan.

Treasury Secretary Stephen Mnuchin already on the ground and he is making news, the dollar is sliding this morning after Secretary Mnuchin said a weaker dollar is good for the U.S. economy and trade during a press conference in Davos. Markets this morning are rallying, take a look at the futures indicating that we will see a higher opening for the broader averages. This right here is the high of the morning. Up better than 100 points in unchartered territory once again. S&P 500 and the NASDAQ also in unchartered territory. The NASDAQ and the S&P hit new record-highs yesterday.

Ahead of the President's trip, investors are watching earning this morning from the likes of General Electric and Comcast among others. G.E. reported earnings and revenue which were below expectation and yet the stock is trading higher. The stock up 2-1/2 percent as investors look for value after a huge selloff. Comcast also topped expectations although that stock is lower. European indices this morning are lower. The stocks in Europe, take a look, are weaker across the board pretty much. FT-100 down one-half of a half percent, the CAC quarante and DAX are also lower. In Asia overnight, markets close mostly higher, take a look. And as you see, the markets were higher with the exception of Japan which was down three- quarters of one percent.

Topping our news this half an hour, President Trump and America First at Davos. More than a dozen high-level members of the administration are arriving here to discuss economics, trade, cybersecurity and a lot more with the political and corporate leaders gathers here. Joining me right now is the United States Secretary of Energy, Secretary Rick Perry. Secretary, it's great to see you.

RICK PERRY, UNITED STATES SECRETARY OF ENERGY: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. The President's America First message, how do you think it will be received?

PERRY: Well, I think he have to understand what America First means to the President and the administration. It's really pretty simple from my perspective. This is about America being competitive around the globe. When folks were thinking about where you want to buy your energy from, where do you want that next load of LNG to come from? We want you to think about America first.

BARTIROMO: Well, that's a good way to put it. Well, the President has stressed really tapping into our oil reserves in America. Let's talk about that and where the opportunities are from your standpoint.

PERRY: Yes. Well, you think about 10 plus years ago and then 2005 we were -- besides ourselves, if you will and behind, other places where the oil and gas was coming from, you know, we had founded all, Peak oil. We heard all of those stories and then, you know, by the grace of God and some technology and a god by named George Mitchell from Texas, hydraulic fracturing came into play in a really big way and we were able to go into those tight shell formations and develop that which is now creating an absolute revolution in the oil and gas industry and completely changing the geopolitical dynamics in the world with America being at the forefront. We are now the number one oil and gas producing nation on the face of the earth. I mean, who would have thought that a decade ago that that would have been true. But it puts us in a very unique place. And here is what I try to share with all of our allies and for all the audience here at Davos is that the United States is not just exporting energy, we're exporting freedom. We're exporting to our allies in Europe. The opportunity to truly have a choice of where do you buy your energy from. That's freedom, and that kind of freedom is priceless.

BARTIROMO: This is a really important point that you're making because for a long time America was reliant on places like Saudi Arabia and Russia to get energy but today it's a completely different situation in America. How significant is it? I mean, how would you characterize the supply that will be coming from the U.S. or to the global markets.

PERRY: You know, I'm not sure anything since World War II has been anymore dynamic from my perspective than they shift in the energy supply, energy control if you will. And again, the United States in the back controlling a country with this industry. It's about literally freeing up our allies around the world. Letting them know that we're going to be there for them, there's no strings attached when you buy American LNG. So, that is -- that's world-changing. And truly, this president, that's his message here. Is that the United States is -- it's a new day. The fossil fuels that we're going to be relying them on for decades to come are going to be available. Now, is our technology going to be able to allow us to use it wiser? With better results for the environment? Absolutely. The CCCU, the carbon capture utilization, we're doing projects with Saudi Arabia.

I'll see my counterpart (INAUDIBLE) today on a panel, we'll talk about the projects that we're working on together. The UAE, Qatar, all of those countries as we come together to develop and supply the rest of the world with the power so that they can have manufacturing (INAUDIBLE) in Africa. Being able to, you know, literally turn the lights on when the sun goes down so that their children can read, the people are safer. I mean, all of that is partly because of American ingenuity and our abilities to not believe the naysayers that people is here and you're not going to find any more of this

BARTIROMO: So, is there -- is there a way to characterize the amount of supply that will be coming from the U.S.?

PERRY: Well, you know, I hesitate to be a forecaster of what the home markets are going to be. I'll leave that up to people that are substantially more into that.

BARTIROMO: Oh, come on. You're the Energy Secretary. Let me ask --

PERRY: My job is to make sure that it's -- the abundant supply and I want to get people together so that they know that America is going to be a reliant supplier of that energy. The price will work itself though.

BARTIROMO: Are you surprised where prices are by the way because it feels like the markets are focused more on the potential for terrorism or disruption. Where oil is right now.

PERRY: Well, those are realities of the world. But the fact is that we have an amazing I mean, you think about Anwar that the Congress just opened up again. You know, the previous administration closed it down, Congress working with the administration said, you know what, those nine million barrels are really important to the United States and to the world. So opening up markets that the previous administration have closed. I think it's in a very powerful message around the world that we're going to be a reliant supplier of energy into the foreseeable future.

BARTIROMO: Absolutely. And I think that's why there's change happening in Saudi Arabia.

PERRY: Indeed.

BARTIROMO: There is incredible change happening in other countries because they see what to expect from the U.S. By the way, what was behind the decision not to drill off of the coast of Florida?

PERRY: You know, I think that the administration through the Department of Interior sensitive to the issues there. There is plenty of space out there whether it's in the gulf, whether it's in Anwar, whether it's other areas that we can develop the energy resource we have. You know, the people of Florida said, hey listen, we don't want to add any new drilling platforms, the administration respected that.

BARTIROMO: And that was OK with the (INAUDIBLE) let me ask you about the President's news this week and that is these tariffs on solar panels and on washing machines, there is some conversation happening and as you know about worries about potential trade wars, about what China will do in response. Should we worry about a different trade stance from this administration?

PERRY: They shouldn't be worrying about this administration from the standpoint of transparency and fairness. That's what Donald Trump is all about. You want to compete against the United States, bring it but don't subsidize in a way that it's unfair, don't get into the market and try to gobble up all the market and then all of a sudden after you choked everybody else out of market, guess what, prices go up. This is a president that says, look, I get it about competition. But you're going to compete fairly, and you're going to compete on a level-playing field.

BARTIROMO: And the President said that as it relates to jobs as well and when you look at the energy story, that's a real job creator. Can you characterize what we might see from all of the drilling and the fracturing that will happen in terms of job creation?

PERRY: Well, it's going to continue on. I mean, that's obviously for the states that --

BARTIROMO: And consistent.

PERRY: And it's not just the jobs right in those states where it's happening, it's upstream or excuse me, it's downstream from that. It's the manufacturing. We think there is an incredible potential in the Appalachian region to turn that area into an absolute job-creating giant with the development of the Marcell or Shell with the other fossil fuels that are available there. You can duplicate the footprint of what you see along in Texas Gulf Coast in that Appalachian region and the jobs that get created. I'm promising you the governor of West Virginia and Ohio and Kentucky and Pennsylvania, they're going to be staying and they're saluting and saying, Mr. President, let's go, let's go make this happen, let's go make America great again.

BARTIROMO: And they're -- and these are high-paying jobs.

PERRY: Indeed. They are.

BARTIROMO: How do you like the job? How do you like the role of energy secretary? What's new that you can tell us with this?

PERRY: Most interesting job I've ever had. Best job ever had was governor of Texas but this one is the most interesting and the coolest job mostly because of the 17 national labs that are out there involved in everything from cybersecurity to the next wave of small-moderate reactors to, you know, just the most fascinating new things that are going to be on the horizon for America. Our national labs are involved in.

BARTIROMO: Secretary, thank you for your leadership.

PERRY: You're welcome.

BARTIROMO: Good to see you. Secretary Rick Perry. We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. General Electric reported earnings that were below expectations, this morning. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange watching the stock trade up -- Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN HOST: Hey, good morning, Maria. We know that General Electric has been in a turnaround phase. In the last August, Flannery came on as the new CEO to turn this thing around. Today, look at that, just in the last half hour, you -- a short time ago, we're saying it was up 2-1/2 percent. And look now, it's up 5.2 percent. So, what happened here? We did see ultimately, that the company in the latest quarter, they're really focusing on the overall -- the restructuring plan. The weakness that they've seen in operating profit and the revenue but ultimately that they're focusing on the aviation and health care divisions where they are seeing some strength.

There has been talk about this company being beaten down, and don't forget, it's down about 45 percent in the last 12 months. Is now the time to finally get into General Electric? I know you've had this conversation with many of your guests, but there's been talk of dividing up the company in some way. But that the turnaround and restructuring is underway, but you are seeing the stock now getting a big jump, Maria. Now, it's up 5-1/2 percent at 17.78. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right. Thank you, Nicole. From Disney to Verizon and Starbucks, more U.S. companies handing out bonus checks, hiking wages for their workers after the tax reform overhaul. Joining me right now, the host of "VARNEY & COMPANY," Stuart Varney to weigh in on that. Stu, it's just incredible the number of companies.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Oh, it's a flood. Look, I would call it a flood. Look, in the last 24 hours, we've got Disney, a thousand bucks to 125,000 employees, Verizon, I think is 2,500 bucks worth of stock to the employees; J.P. Morgan 10 percent wage increases for a big swath of their people. I mean, it's a long list, just in last 24 hours. It's clear, I think American business was on trial, they got everything they wanted from the tax cut deal, and now, they are indeed passing it along to the -- to the customers and also to their employees. But, you know, the big pass-through, I think, is still to come. I think that will come from the big tech companies of this world, when they repatriate all of that money. I think a lot of it goes to shareholders. And looking for stock buybacks like Comcast, for example, and I'm looking also for a dividend increases. That's the next round in this flood of pass-throughs and givebacks. Here it comes.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's a great point. I would also add on to financial services, Stu, because, you know, the banks really haven't even had the actual impact of regulation rollback. You know, that's to come, so there's this enormous runway there as well.

VARNEY: Yes, look, it's a flood, that's what I'm saying. By the way, how is Davos treating you? Are being nice to you?

BARTIROMO: It's good. I mean, you know, everyone's talking about President Trump.

VARNEY: Exactly.

BARTIROMO: Coming tomorrow, and wondering what he's going to say, so he's definitely making a splash even before he arrives, Stu.

VARNEY: Stick it to them, Mr. President

(LAUGHTER)

BARTIROMO: We'll see you in 10 min, Stu.

VARNEY: You will.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour, right after "MORNINGS WITH MARIA". We'll be right back.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Tax reform trickle down, Verizon, Disney, Starbucks have all announced perks for their employees as a result of the new tax cuts. Joining me right now live from the World Economic Forum is the CEO of Campbell Soup, Denise Morrison. Denise, great to see you, thanks so much for joining us.

DENISE MORRISON, CEO, CAMPBELL SOUP: Hi, Maria.

BARTIROMO: What's your take on the tax package?

MORRISON: Well, I think the tax reform will be beneficial for business. We at Campbell's are going to realize a benefit from the reduced rate being largely United States company, we bear a rate over 30 percent and we expected that will come down pretty significantly. And what we're going to do with that is invest in our brands and pay down debt because we just made a very large acquisition.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Let's talk about that acquisition. How does this acquisition fill in the whole that you were looking to do? What -- how does it give you a scale and tell us about the growth that you're expecting as a result?

MORRISON. Yes. Well, we've been on a journey to transform Campbell's and to transition our portfolio. Soup is a very important category but we now recognize that in order to deliver on the needs and wants of the next generation of consumers, we wanted to diversify our portfolio in the faster-growing spaces, and those spaces are health and well-being and snacking. And so, acquisitions were the key accelerator for that strategy.

BARTIROMO: And Lance, $50 a share in cash. A lot of people talked about this as really helping Snyder's-Lance -- helping the company fill in areas because people are looking for healthier options, wellness. Tell us about it.

MORRISON: We believe that this provides a snacking platform, a diversified snacking platform because we already have Pepperidge Farm, Arnott's, and Kelsen, so this adds more to the savory snacks in addition to the sweet snacks. And then if you start to think about our simple meals as convenient mini meals, it's right on trend with what the consumer is doing because, Maria, only 34 percent of consumers eat three square meals a day. Over 90 percent are snacking five times a day, so this is right on trend.

BARTIROMO: Interesting. So, the soup category, is that slowing down? I know the last quarter, a lot of people were worried that it showed that we're seeing a bit of a slowdown.

MORRISON: Yes, there are pockets of growth in the soup category, for example, we introduced a new Well Yes! Product that we co-created with consumers, and that's targeted for the younger generation, all clean label soups, so you can read every ingredient on the label, ingredients like quinoa and kale, right on trend. We also just closed on the acquisition of Pacific Foods, which is a soup and broth and plant-based beverage company. We're very excited about that company, and the growth rate of that brand is really exciting. So, we are starting to move into new spaces even within the soup category.

BARTIROMO: You've got to change as consumer tastes change and people are looking for healthier options like the kale and quinoa.

MORRISON: It always starts with the consumer. And if you keep your eye on the consumer, they will take you where you need to go. And we spend lots of times with the consumers, we shop with them, we cook with them, we eat with them. Our team is having so much fun, sometimes it's hard to get them to come back to work.

BARTIROMO: So, growth comes from acquisitions or organic?

MORRISON: Growth comes from both. You need to be innovation -- you have to have organic innovation and really push the thinking, you have to do some acquisitions but you also have to --

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Thanks for joining us, everybody, we'l1 see you tomorrow. Here's Stuart and "VARNEY & COMPANY." Stu?

VARNEY: Thanks very much, Maria. All right.

END

This one  doesn't.  This administration has been unafraid to roll back <xhtml:span class="hit">regulations</xhtml:span> that make no sense. We felt it. We're feeling it on ...</xhtml:span>
